												You can call me a hipster, but I like this one more than the original or Infinite. There's just something about this particular story, these particular characters and this particular Rapture, that was amiss in the other two. While Bioshock established Rapture as a location and told a story of its founder, Bioshock 2 focuses more on the lives of Rapture's ordinary inhabitants, and boy, does it add to the immersion. The storyline is less linear, allowing an option to spare or kill not only Little Sisters, but bosses as well, which leads to one of 6 endings.The core of the gameplay stayed almost untouched since the original Bioshock, but with some new features. Action-packed harvesting sessions and Big Sister fights are intertwined with the calm and tranquil seabed walks. In addition to previously seen weapons, you have Big Daddy's iconic drill and Rivet Gun at your disposal. Also, you can use both weapons and plasmids in a fight, without swapping one for the other (for me personally it seemed kind of stupid that it wasn't like this all along).In short, if you just finished Bioshock, and can't get enough of Rapture, get Bioshock 2 in a heartbeat. You won't regret it.Also, playing as a Big Daddy is beyond cool. 10 drill dashes out of 10.

												Bioshock 2 is a huge disappointment in comparison to Bioshock. The game's story was kinda blah, and well felt in it's own way too similar to the first. Unlike some I thought it was cool that it was in Rapture again, but they did not have to have the story completly the same.In Bioshock 2 the game is much different. In Bioshock 2 you are a Big Daddy. Instead of tommy guns, pistols etc. for weapons, you get Big Daddy weapons. This may sound cool, but it is not as exciting as it sounds. The game is in many ways babified, in they simplified things that did not need it. The hacking was simplified so easy a child could do it, and they give guides for things like the eve system that were straightforward to begin with. The game in general also feels more simplistic than the first Bioshock.The Multi-player was really blah and I think they could have made a better single-player if they spent more resources on the single-player instead.I originally owned Bioshock 2 on the Xbox 360 and got it in a 3 pack on steam for PC. On the Xbox 360 the game was stable, on the PC you have to turn off advanced graphics features offered by DirectX 10 to prevent it from constantly crashing, which is pathetic. I guess I would be mad if I did not get it almost free.I highly recommend getting Bioshock 1 if you have not played it, I only recommend 2 if you want to see what the story is like. I warn you, you will probably be disappointed. The only reason I am playing through it again is to get the steam achievements.

												TL;DR: Bioshock 2 is better than Bioshock 1 and you should definitely buy it.Improvements over Bioshock 1:-Dual wield plasmids and guns-More smooth gameplay-Level 3 plasmid upgrades-More moral choices-Your choices having a more detailed impact on the ending-Better preformance on newer systems-Some cool new Plasmids-A few new guns-More unique gun upgrades-Deeper exploration between litle sister/big daddy link-Cool multiplayer (pretty much dead now, but it's there)Improvements in my opinion (subjective):-More empathetic main villain-A better final boss fight-Cooler companion characters-I love the little sister defence sectionsNeutral:-Same environment style. Just as good as 1, but we're used to it by now so it's not as effective-Several Plasmids are reusedWeaknesses to Bioshock 1:-Stealth is nowhere near as prominant-A few bits of the story drag (Looking at you, Siren's Alley)-You'll be swimming in loot at the end of the game, removing most challenge-Doesn't have a huge twist in itOverall, this is a game that got alot of bad rep at launch just because it wasn't made by the orignal creators. Still, it's easy to see lot's of love went into this game. In fact, a few of the ideas from Bioshock 2 were taken into Bioshock Infinite. content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												BioShock 2 is one of my favourite games. Some time after it came out, I saw it was getting spit on and dismissed, but I didn't really pay attention to that, as I assumed it was the all too well known kneejerk reaction of the smug fanboy portion of the players.I got it and went in unbiased. I don't want to compare it to the others in terms of which I think is best, because I love them all separately and as a whole, but it does quite a few things better than the other two titles. What I can say is, I think 2 had the best combat out of the games, because there were so many possibilities, especially with the dual-wielding and the plasmid trap combos. That's not to say I think the combat in 1 or Infinite wasn't good; in fact, I liked it in both games, although less in Infinite. Of course, the latter had a variety of Vigor and weapon combos as well, but not nearly as big as 2.BioShock 2 also improved on many mechanics like the Camera, plasmid use, hacking, Little Sister interactions, upgrading, as well as things like the visuals and more. However, what I most love about it is the bond I felt with Eleanor and how my actions actually changed her character and demeanor. I really wanted to help her, I wanted her to be safe. And seeing the statues of me rescuing the NPCs through the Little Sister's eyes really made me emotional, as did the whole Little Sister adoption and subsequent saving mechanics. It was so touching to see how playing a merciful, forgiving Delta changed how the NPCs reacted to you and pretty much established you as the most human character in the game, even though you were, as Sinclaire roughly put it, a "tin man". And who can forget the Big Sister fights? They were the ultimate test for your skills, weapons, plasmids. And the ending monologue Eleanor does for the best ending, as well as that pan of Rapture with the main theme of the first game and her saying, "And then, Father, the Rapture dream was over." Man. That was one of the several moments in the game where I teared up and felt introspective about the whole (at the time) BioShock world."The Ocean On His Shoulders". How fitting indeed.I really like Lamb as a villain as well, because she was so different, yet almost as well-designed as Andrew Ryan in some aspects.I was invested all the way throughout BioShock 2, as I was with 1 and Infinite. I went in without prejudice and I got one hell of a good game out of it, so I can strongly recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Review for Bioshock: Here.Review for Bioshock Remastered: Here.**Note: This is NOT a review for the Remastered version. If you would like to see my Bioshock 2 Remastered review, please click here.*Excuse the play hours. I've much more on console and the Remastered version.When Bioshock 2 was announced, it unleashed a shock-wave of excitement throughout the gaming community; its predecessor had been a monumental success, and people could not wait to see what the sequel had in store. Born three long years after the original title, it's safe to say that Bioshock 2 did not disappoint in terms of gameplay, visuals, and setting, although many fans agree that the plot and characters are not quite as memorable as those from the first installment.The game begins in the year 1958, two years prior to the events of the first Bioshock, and shows the main character that you play, known as Subject Delta, patrolling Rapture with his Little Sister, Eleanor. Some events happen, and the game fast forwards ten years later to the year 1968 (not 1970 as the store page misleads you to believe). Subject Delta, also known as Johnny Topside prior to his conversion into a Big Daddy, has set out to find Eleanor, who is now a young adult in her teens. Time is pressing, however, as the longer a Big Daddy is away from his Little Sister, the higher the odds of him slipping into a coma are. There's but one problem standing in your way, a highly manipulative and slightly insane woman named Sophia Lamb. She has replaced Andrew Ryan as the main antagonist, while Augustus Sinclair helps guide you throughout Rapture through radio messages. Yes, you read that right. This time around, you get to play as an actual Big Daddy; arguably the most appealing feature of the entire game. You can also take on other Big Daddies to take their Little Sisters, and you can protect them as they're harvesting ADAM from angels. After letting the Little Sister gather from two angels, you take her back to her vent and choose to either harvest or rescue her. Harvesting or rescuing Little Sisters has an impact on the end game cutscene, and there are a total of three different endings. New to the tried and true Splicers and Big Daddies are now Big Sisters, which wear much of the same gear as a Big Daddy but they're much slimmer, quicker, and deadlier.Another improvement to the gameplay is the ability to wield both a weapon and a Plasmid at the same time, where as in the original Bioshock you had to constantly swap between the two. However, there's a huge glitch in the game that causes your left arm, which is the one that uses Plasmids, to disappear until you either die or get talked to by Eleanor. There are also a new assortment of weapons, such as the drill, grenade launcher, and speargun, and there are a mix of new and old Plasmids to enjoy as well, 11 in total.Bioshock 2 feels a lot more linear than its predecessor, as there aren't as many non-essential rooms to explore. However, the lush environments and fantastic atmosphere more than make up for the overall closed maps. A huge feature, aside from being a Big Daddy of course, is being able to occasionally venture outside of Rapture, onto the ocean floor. The oceanic scenes and moments spent underwater are beautifully crafted, and make you realize just how small you are in comparison to the immense structure that is the city of Rapture. The Art Deco style has been down-scaled in this installment in lieu of a more steampunk style, which ends up coming full circle in Bioshock Infinite.One thing that really brought this game down was the inclusion of a multiplayer element. I'm not even sure if the servers are still active anymore, but I did play some multiplayer on console when the game was brand new. Like most games that should stay as a single player experience but don't, the multiplayer was terrible and mostly consisted of death matches between Big Daddies and Splicers. I'm not alone in my distaste for the multiplayer element, as you will see most other reviewers also scorn it as well. This 'feature', however, has been dropped in the Bioshock 2 Remastered version.Is Bioshock 2 better than the first game? Absolutely not. It's nowhere near as memorable in terms of story or plot, but the gameplay is where this title really shines. Playing as a Big Daddy is satisfying in every imaginable way, from the killing and being able to use a drill, to protecting Little Sisters and helping them harvest ADAM. It's the experience that fans would've been continuing to ask for until we got it, but luckily 2K had the foresight to just go ahead and do it. Sophia Lamb is definitely not as charming a villain as Andrew Ryan or Atlas, but she does have her moments. It's a worthwhile experience for the fan of the Bioshock universe, just don't go in expecting as gripping of a tale.Rating: 4.0/5.0 - Excellent, highly worth playing.𐌕𐋏𐌄 𐋏𐍈𐍂𐍂𐍈𐍂 𐌽𐌄𐌕𐤔𐍈𐍂𐌊 Curator | Group 𐌂𐌋𐌆𐌂𐌊 𐌅𐍈𐍂 𐌾𐍈𐍂𐌄

content:
Posted: April 20
												   Though not lead by the same team that made Bioshock 1, Bioshock 2 somehow surpasses its predecsessor in many aspects. Little annoyances from Bioshock have been fixed, and core pieces of the gameplay have been expanded upon to deliever a more fufilling overall experience. Things like the Hack Gun, which allows for long distance hacking, and the much needed duel wielding of plasmids and primaries smooth out kinks and polish the Bioshock formula to a shine.   The little sister/big daddy system from the original has also been expanded, and the gameplay and story integration really hits a peak here. You are the big daddy now, and these little girls are yours to protect. No other game has been able to match the sheer burst of primal anger you get when the sound of that child crying for help echoes through the room. Pitty the poor fool who dared to lay a hand on Your little sister.    Not spoiling anything here, the story is quite heartfelt: Your role as a big daddy delivers some crucial context to the lives of these hulking protectors, and the relationship they have with both the little ones and the city as a whole. You'll come out of the experience (assuming you didnt harvest the girls like a complete monster) feeling, for lack of better words, like a dad. A proud one at that.   Though not anything really new in relation to the first game, Bioshock 2 delivers what I personally believe to be Bioshock at its smoothest and most polished. Worth every penny. tldr: Its Good, You're a Dad Now. Congratulations.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												Bioshock 2 is very similar to Bioshock, which is a steam-punk version of System Shock.The story is as interesting and with the same gradual build-up to the peak dramatic intensity of the ending, which is great. Although, some things are confusing, e.g., only after watching an explanation on YouTube, did I understand that Bioshock 2 protagonist is not the same as in Bioshock.They simplified the hacking system, made it more faster. The hacking in the first part was overkill.The enemies are basically the same, only brute splicers and big sisters are introduced. And it's fine with me. What else to think of, if it's the same environment with the same inhabitants?In overall, I can say that Bioshock 2 doesn't offer nothing radically new, it feels more like a remake – the way the Bioshock should have been made.Bioshock 2 offers a smooth RPG-FPS experience with an interesting story. It feels somewhat repetitive, as I approach each level in the same way and all the levels feel the same, too, although the difficulty is gradually increasing. At times I felt almost bored, but the last 2 levels compensate for that, as the story gets really interesting. And the ending is really, really cool. As in the first part, it is determined by your moral choices during the game.My overall rating is 7/10. It's a good game, but I wouldn't recommend to play it right after you have finished the first part, as they are very similar and you might get fed up with the Rapture environment.It's also quite short (less than 14 hours to complete the story), but, I guess, if it was longer, it might have been overkill.The game also has extra missions (to defend little sisters in different levels), which I personally didn't find interesting to try, and MP, which also offers some co-op challenges, however it is almost dead and it's hard to find at least 4 players to fill the arena.The Minerva Den DLC: a nice addition to the core game. 7/10. Reveals the true identity of the protagonist.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												To help put things in perspective, know that I first had completed Bioshock 1 and Infinite in my gaming lifetime. An odd order, yes. But it did help put things in perspective, both the evolution of the series as well as the reviews associated with it.In terms of gameplay, Bioshock 2 is a straight upgrade from 1. The looting and exploration is just as enjoyable as it was before, and bullet stock micromanagers will have a moderately satisfying day. The game isn't too hard, even on the highest difficulty. It may be rough to start out, as you don't have the Plasmids and Tonics yet that befit your playstyle. But as time passes on, you will be able to gather your bearings. As long as you somewhat try to use your ammo sparingly or at least wisely, you will have maximum ammo on most of your weapons, and your wallet will be full as well.A feature I've always liked, as money in this game isn't as much a currency as it is a resource which you can hold only a limited amount of. I've always admired how Bioshock's "Money" dynamic made it stand apart from many other shooters and RPG's and what not.When keeping visual design in mind, changing from a 'human splicer' in the predecessor to an 'alpha version Big Daddy' brings a visual change that really helps you immerse in the role. All the former weapons are present, but in bulky versions befitting what you are. The revolver is replaced with a Rivet Gun, but still fires just like it, the pump shotgun with a double barrel one and the crossbow with a spear launcher. It's a detail, but an important one.As a Big Daddy, you are still tasked to defeat other Big Daddy's to lay claim on their LIttle Sister. With the new weaponry and evolved plasmids, this task has become much more interesting. Setting up traps and following your plan like a script will help you get some proper first blood damage in, and then you can finish off the bugger with your weaponry. A task that is still quite intimidating, as the melee Daddies still know how to quickly close in on you, and the ranged ones carry some very hefty firepower. Even as a Big Daddy yourself, you'll need to Tonic up before you can take a prolonged beating. Wits are still very much required.And these wits will serve you well, as now you can fullfill your role as Big Daddy when finally claiming a big sister. Beyond the options you had in the first game, you can also have the Little Sister harvest ADAM from specific corpses. Each little sister can only harvest twice, and there's always more corpses than can be used. So exploration for more ideal locations does pay off.Which is where your trap laying skills yet again prove handy. Instead of taking on a mobile Big Daddy, you now need to strategically defend a stationary target while she drains adam. The act of draining seems to always attract a big crowd of Splicers. And it needs no explaining that the Splicer AI is well capable of ambushing you now if you think of cheesing it out.Not to mention the Big Sisters, who always come for you when all the Little Sisters in the level have been dealt with. They are pretty much twice as strong as a Big Daddy, much more agile and beat your face hard with an array of Plasmid skills. Being unprepared generally leaves you dead and beaten.But worry not, because you've got a new wide array of new and/or improved Plasmids to help you defend. Whirlwind Trap alone is a poster boy of this, as you can now imbue Level 2 traps with any other Plasmid skill you have, adding a unique feature to the trap. Ranging from Shock and Fire, to Hypnotise traps. The latter is especially handy to place with a Little Sister, in case a Splicer reaches her. Send that f*cker right back to fight his friends, or into another trap.Pretty much all Plasmids gain unique features with every level. But the Tonics get very interesting as well. Basic ones as Boozehound are now accompanied with reducing Eve usage, and there even is a Tonic in the late game where you can drastically reduce your Eve usage in return for only using your Drill (your new Melee weapon). I have tried the Melee build, using damage reduction and melee damage increase, and I can guarantee you that it's quite viable. Doing a Drill Charge (a skill the storyline will teach you) is very satisfying and lethal, although quite taxing on your Drill Fuel.Speaking of the Story...It's a mixed feeling. Of course it's not as impressive as the first one was. That said, it would take exceptional work to make that even possible. The story isn't bad, and certainly gives you enough encouragement to go on, it's just not as good...Which does explain why Infinite tried so hard to focus on it's story counterpart, sadly leaving behind some of the features we had loved the first two for.If you liked Bioshock 1 and want more of it, this game is absolutely worth it. If you think Infinite couldn't get any better... well, maybe you'll like it less, but it might still be worth it to put some context to some of the Infinite DLC.All in all I would say it's been a worthy successor, filling that Bioshock hunger I was having.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												It's absolutely fascinating - and a trademark of the Bioshock series - how Minerva's Den manages to turn a plot about regaining control of a central computer into one of the greatest love stories told in videogames.Also, one little detail at the end of Minerva's Den gives us - in retrospect - a measure of the savvy with which the world of Bioshock is constructed: in the office of Charles Milton Porter you find a color TV (http://bioshock.wikia.com/wiki/File:Standby_tv_color.png) powered up by three brightly colored tubes that stick oddly into it. Playing through both Bioshocks you see so many grayscale / sepia monitors (most of them with that frozen 'Please Stand By' logo on them) that they actually become a trademark for the series. And at the end of Minerva's Den when you see that color monitor you cannot help but feel that it doesn't belong there, that it cannot be 'in' Rapture, it must be there from somewhere else, from another world, like a seed of a new world that sprouts in dying Rapture, maybe, and you get the feeling that not only the ocean is finding its way into the ruined city, but another - more colorful - world is also leaking through the cracks in Rapture's broken reality and this could be, in retrospect, the moment that Bioshock's universe opens up to the Multiverse that will take the stage in Infinite.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												For those of you who have played the original Bioshock, you will be right at home in Bioshock 2. For the rest of you, go play the original Bioshock first; if you don't you will be more than a little confused.A little background first: both games take place in a city called Rapture located on the floor of the Atlantic Ocean. It was created as a utopia where you could choose your own destiny without the interference of governments or organized religion. As you can imagine this didn't last, and by the time you show up in the first game Rapture has deteriorated into a big free-for-all. The man who created Rapture, Andrew Ryan, serves as the main antagonist in the first game.The second game takes place eight years after the first one, which is surprising because I can't believe that the city continued to function for that long. You play as a Big Daddy who has been gone from Rapture for ten years.The city is now under the control of a psychiatrist named Sofia Lamb, and you have plenty of reasons to hate her. In direct contrast to Ryan's exaltation of the individual, Lamb is all about everyone working together. I find it interesting that all of these people who came to Rapture specifically for self-determination are suddenly working for Lamb.In Bioshock the end cutscene depended on what you did to the Little Sisters you found: did you save them or harvest them? In Bioshock 2 there was more to it. In addition to the Little Sisters, there were several characters who you could decide to spare or kill; different situations surround each choice. I have heard that there are something like 12 different endings to the game depending on what you decide to do. This is one of the significant things that they improved over the original game in my opinion.Other than that though I felt that the story wasn't quite as good as the original. While it wasn't too difficult to understand where Andrew Ryan was coming from when he went on his rants, I really couldn't understand the reasoning behind Sofia Lamb's plan to create a perfect society. Speaking of Ryan, many of the characters and recordings talked about him and their opinions of how he ran things; clearly Rapture was still living in his shadow 8 years later. I felt like Bioshock 2 was similarly living in its predecessor's shadow, especially because the creative minds behind the first game (read: Ken Levine) weren't directly involved in the second.The area that Bioshock 2 made huge improvements in was the gameplay. In the original game you had to switch between your weapon and plasmid, but in the second you always had both available to you. This alone made battles much more fast-paced and hectic. There was also more variety in enemy types; the splicers are a lot more deformed, presumable due to the extra years since the first game, and there are now brute splicers. They aren't quite as tough as Big Daddies but they fill in the gap between weak foes and really tough ones. The scariest enemy that they added was the Big Sister. They come after you sometimes after you have rescued a Little Sister, and they are tough. They use plasmids and melee attacks, and they are extremely nimble. I couldn't get a screenshot of them while they were alive because I was too busy trying to shoot them, but here is a dead one.There were new weapons as well: the metal pipe you wielded in the original game is replaced by the Big Daddy's Drill, and I took malicious pleasure in pinning enemies to walls from afar with the new spear gun.raphically Bioshock 2 is beautiful. The environment was almost identical to the original, but you can immediately tell the difference when you look at character models from the two games.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												After I finished the original Bioshock 1 I immediately wanted the sequel to see how it would continue and what happened after the first game. I wanted a game that would show me just what happened after Jack left Rapture and the city was left to rot for 10 years at the bottom of the ocean. I guess I got just what I want, which is probably my main complaint about this game. It feels like afterwash from the original in a way that it feels like I'm playing a DLC for the original or maybe even reading a fan continuation. The environments you got to explore, while still pretty cool, weren't usually as big or as major to Rapture as the ones and Bioshock 1. I feel like they should have added the older locations into this game on top of the fresh environments to make it feel like you're going through the same city. Also, to make sure that people don't get confused about the lore, no more bathyspheres. The story isn't anything to write home about, either. You control a special Big Daddy named Subject Delta who, can you guess what the main conflict is going to be? Yeah, he's looking for his Little Sister who was kidnapped. I mean, she was already kidnapped, but she was... Kidnapped... Back... It's a bit predictable, unlike the Bioshock 1, but the story still held suprises for me, even without a major twist in the middle. The characters have to be either the best or the worst thing in this game when it comes down to it. I really liked the characters like Sinclair, who reminded me of Atlas from the first game and Eleanor, your little/big sister. The antagonist was... Okay to say the least. Like the first game it had a pretty powerful message with it but I felt she talked a little too much. I know. It's a pretty stupid thing to complain about, but when she radios you every 5 MINUTES SAYING THE EXACT SAME f*$#ING THING OVER AND OVER AGAIN YOU GET A BIT TIRED, OKAY? As for the other characters, they were kind-of forgettable. Each section has a different character belonging to it, and at the end you get to either kill or spare them. Now, the endings system is alot bigger than Bioshock 1's was as in there are 6 endings instead of just 2. It has the same Harvest or Rescue Little Sisters system (with a fun Little Sisters protect minigame thing!) But, like I said, it also has different characters to kill or to claim mercy on. First is Grace, who I could understand sparing. The second guy I could also understand sparing and still being labeled as good. But the third guy, oh my gosh why are you even supposed to spare him and still be labeled as good? He begs you to kill him in audio recordings because he's insane and he is a giant mutant blob who can't move for Gods sake! How are you helping ANYONE by not killing him? I actually didn't know what to do when I got to this point because they both seemed bad thing to do. If you do kill him, you get labeled as a murderer in the ending, though! But what about those hundreds of splicers and big daddies you mowed through like overgrown weeds! They're insane too, but don't they deserve a chance at life if a giant mutant blob who can't move does? All in all, I liked the new gameplay and plasmid system. The weapons for your Big Daddy self were also really cool. I especially liked the one where you could hack from a distance or place mini turrets. Anyway, that's just my two cents on this game. If you enjoyed the first I would recommend it for everything it has to offer.

I will keep the short but sweet. First let me answer any question about the game.1- Do I need to play Bioshock 1 to know the goings on in the 2nd?. Answer is no.You will get many spoilers of what happened in the 1st game though.2- Is the 1st game worth playing? Everything moves more fluid and does not feel lagged at all. The A.I. is as always an enjoyable treat to encounter though the creepy & horror filled vibe that the first held us to seems not present here.However the story of the character you're playing contains the majority of the horror. I won't spoil but you really feel for the guy but not attached to him. Weapon variety is the same as in Bioshock 1 along side the 3 ammo types per weapon/tool. New though is a hacking tool which lets you remotely hack from a distance,very handy and needed in some situations.New plasmids and tonics make a debut as well increasing the variety without detracting ones from the 1st game.There are new variety of Big Daddies this time around along side the old ones of Bioshock 1.New splicers and turrent turrent types make a debut. 												 First of all I want to say that this is a review on the singleplayer + minerva's dlc since I've played only those, multiplayer wise I didn't try it or know if there is anyone playing it. I know people think about these game a step backwards from bioshock 1 but I'm inclined to say that I enjoyed bioshock 2 more, I say this because combat wise I say it's better having the ability of just having one power in one hand and on the other your weapon is such a better way of playing this game, I found that bioshock 1 was a bit clunky with that.  The difficulty on this game was harder (played both on hard) than bioshock 1 it had more variety and although big daddies were easier these variety made a difference, in minerva's den though lancers and alphas were much harder even on late build but big sisters were the same it would be just a matter of having the resources or not which I found on Minerva's Dlc to be harder to come by which made a huge difference in most battles. So this is what I liked a lot on bioshock story was also really good, found it more appealing than the first one.  Now for the bad parts which enraged me I will say that for you to play this you need to save manually instead of quick saving because you will get your save corrupted and it will not be fun the only thing that made me keep playing this game and finishing was that it was really good, which is a good thing but for the interesting part about why your save gets corrupted it's the constant crashing to your desktop that happens, I probably had only one boss battle that I didn't had to beat twice due to this constant crashing. But this is not the only bad parts, the controls are cr*p who the f**k uses the "T" key to zoom in your weapon? But it's rebindable so you can put your right mouse to zoom in which previously was for your plasmids which in your screen is the left hand so you are shooting plasmids in your right mouse? Wtf and also the game has a mechanic which I don't know why when you have a lot of ammo the game automatically changes from time to time to your other ammo and I got parts in the game where I was shooting with the rivet gun or spear gun trap rivets into bigsister face which she really enjoyed because it did crap damage. In the end though with these 3 negative problems which were persistent to say the least I enjoyed the game a lot and if it was not for that I would be bashing this game but it was good and I recommend it, can't compare it to infinite though because it's the next on bioshock series that I'm going to play.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
I will keep the short but sweet. First let me answer any question about the game.1- Do I need to play Bioshock 1 to know the goings on in the 2nd?. Answer is no.You will get many spoilers of what happened in the 1st game though.2- Is the 1st game worth playing? Extremely it is held by many as the best game of the bioshock series,its a personal favorite game of all time of mine. 3- Is the Minerva's Den DLC worth playing? Yes it is, its about 5 hours long depending on how much explorinig and 100% stuff you do.The story some consider better than the story of Bio 2. I personally found both stories to be about the same but not impressive like Bioshock 1.Now on with the short n sweet review.Bioshock 2 has a improved combat system over the 1st game. Everything moves more fluid and does not feel lagged at all. The A.I. is as always an enjoyable treat to encounter though the creepy & horror filled vibe that the first held us to seems not present here.However the story of the character you're playing contains the majority of the horror. I won't spoil but you really feel for the guy but not attached to him. Weapon variety is the same as in Bioshock 1 along side the 3 ammo types per weapon/tool. New though is a hacking tool which lets you remotely hack from a distance,very handy and needed in some situations.New plasmids and tonics make a debut as well increasing the variety without detracting ones from the 1st game.There are new variety of Big Daddies this time around along side the old ones of Bioshock 1.New splicers and turrent turrent types make a debut. The enivornments are familiar to Bioshock 1, but not as horrific as it. Quite a few pieces of background info regarding the 1st games characters are found throughout the game shedding more light to the behind the scenes of what happened. The game has a lot going for it, its just many story telling elements were a miss unlike in the first game.If you are a Bioshock fan its worth playing,just I doubt you will make a return to Bioshock 2 unlike 1.Like it or not, its a part of the franchise but story wise skippable in relation to the bigger story of the trilogy.This game is more a "day in the life of a rapture citizen" type of thing.Just you are a V.I.P.Tech IssuesThere are some steps you may or may not need to go through before you can enjoy the game as much as possible.I have a Nvidia 450 GTS 1gb vram with its latest drivers and a AMD Phenom II X4 920 2.80 ghz on Win7 64 Pro  and even after doing the crashing tutorial I got crashes periodically. I had the game on Win Vista compatibilty mode with admin privilages turn on.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												Bioshock 2 has a rather unfavourable reputation. It's seen as so non-canon, so unambitious that rarely is it discussed by fans and critics in the same breath as other 'Shock games. But Bioshock 2 isn't for those people. Bioshock 2 is a game for people who want to creep around more of the Bioshock 1 universe, were rather fond of the gameplay of the original and fancy properly stepping into the shoes of a Big Daddy as opposed to the shallow facsimile at the end of the first game. Even though it might be hitting on the same beats, Bioshock 2 isn't aiming to be the revolutionary, disorienting, dramatic tour-de-force the first game was, or the one Infinite was trying so hard to be, and that's just fine. Instead, it just wears the first game's clothes and tries really hard, like an endearing little brother. It's almost like a ridiculously well-produced fan game or total conversion mod. Accept the game for what it is, and Bioshock 2 actually becomes a rather lighthearted experience. It's easy to have fun with it when you know not to take it so seriously, especially when its got the presentation and solidness of a Bioshock game.

												Walk into the footsteps of a Big Daddy in Rapture. 10 years ago, you were doing a routine walk with your Little Sister. Now, she is kidnapped and you were knocked out for that duration. Welcome back to the beauty and glory of Rapture...now, quit standing around and work with Sinclair to save your Eleanor who is being manipulated by Lamb!This game has the same single-player feel from the first Bioshock, but with a few changes(i.e hacking). Your actions will affect Eleanor, so choose wisely on what you want her to become! During that time, as Sinclair says, "You and me, kid. We're going places."For the multiplayer version, however, could have met it's potential. There are many problems with it. First thing is that it uses peer 2 peer technology for connection with players around the world. There is no option whatsoever to host a dedicated server. You just find a room with the type of game, and that's it. Second, there are a lot of disrespectful people that come online. There is no option to mute them or ignore them, and even ignoring them on Steam doesn't help. Third, by default, your mic is on by using whatever settings you have on Windows(even if you don't have a mic, it goes onto Stereo Mix recording).TL;DR. Single Player is awesome. Multiplayer is good, but with too many problems.

Set years after the orignal release in bioshock 2 you play as a failed 'prototype' big daddy which i think was a great feature. content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												A wonderful sequel to the first BioShock but this time developed by 2K. BioShock 2 does not really offer anything new; it just improves upon the first game. It is an interesting concept to put the player into the shoes of a Big Daddy - it should be mentioned that it is an alpha version, though, so it's not like you are an all powerful being incapable of dying. Still, it is a nice touch as you can finally use a Big Daddy's drill and while in the prequel you just killed these monstrous creatures to get hold of the little girls now you have to protect the children while they harvest ADAM from the fallen citizens of Rapture. Again, these encounters are optional but well worth the trouble. And once you completed all harvests the Big Sister appears. This is an addition to the boss battles and while the Big Daddies are slow their sisters are much faster so you need to use different tactics.Other than the harvest part the gameplay remains similar. You keep progressing further and while the game is linear you should look behind every door and open every box to find loot and the good-old audio diaries that further explain the background. Morality choices return but with greater impact and this time you have 3 endings available. Hacking can be done from the distance by shooting darts into the target objects and instead of taking pictures you have a camera that can record your battles with your foes. Again, recording here results in bonuses against the various types of enemies. Many plasmid types return but there are new additions to an already varied rooster and levelling up them offers better bonuses. We now have multiplayer but personally I found it just average - I guess this was the usual attempt to lengthen the game's replayability but the single player offers at least 3 playthroughs so I believe it was unnecessary. I do not think anybody plays multiplayer anymore, either.This is the first BioShock that comes with a DLC. On Steam the DLC is part of the game and it should be mentioned that they got rid of GFWL (good riddance!) so we should not bother with this, thank god. Minerva's Den offers us a completely new plot - again, we play as an Alpha Series Big Daddy - and we get a deeper insight into the city's inner workings.BioShock 2 is an example of what a true sequel should be. It improves upon an already very good BioShock 1, thus, it feels like as if we continued the story where we left off and did not stop playing BioShock.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												If popular opinion is to be believed, Bioshock 2 is a game that suffers under the shadow of the remarkable first game in the series, which is mostly regarded as being the better of the two journeys into the depths of Rapture (that is, if one can actually classify separate journeys into the depths of madness and depravity as being somehow being “better” than one another).  Some of this opinion is warranted, but in other crucial ways this game actually manages to outshine its older sibling.Let’s talk a bit about story and setting, as I feel that these two elements define the heart of the Bioshock experience.  Much like its antagonist, the first game was responsible for creating Rapture, the ugly, decrepit, and rusted out undersea dystopia.  In Bioshock 2 well you’ll sure see more … of the same.  The trouble with a setting like Rapture really is that it’s a bit self-contained, both literally and figuratively.  It’s wonderfully detailed, and there are hundreds of stories to be told (as evidenced by the many audio diaries that reappear in this game), but it’s still a microcosm.  So Bioshock 2 returns you to the same old Rapture you've seen before, to visit the same old menagerie of drug addled psychos you've set on fire before.  In a lesser setting this might prove to be an issue, but that’s just it; the world of Rapture has enough texture and atmosphere that it can still stand strong even if you do have some sense of déjà vu upon your return.  The weight of dread, hopelessness, and despair bears down on you every bit as much as the weight of the ocean around you, which in turn allows you to once again soak in the experience of Rapture.In terms of story, your reaction may depend on how you feel about canon and its role in a larger story arc.  Indeed there are some potential issues here in terms of overall canon.  It takes some firm suspension of disbelief to swallow the premise that the Rapture we saw in the first game survived another 10 minutes after our first departure, much less another 8 years.  The character of Sofia Lamb is bolted on to the canon in such a way that it begs the question, if Lamb was such a prominent figure in Rapture, why did we not hear of her in the first game?  How are there still splicers down here, being that they seem to be a pretty nonfunctional self-destructive lot, and I can’t imagine that they’d be capable of reproduction (nor would I want to … ewww).  So yes, there may be some issues with Bioshock 2 in terms of the overall canon of the series, but here’s the clincher, and a statement which may net me some detractors.  If you can look past the minor issues above, the story in Bioshock 2 is actually better than the first game.  Sorry Ken Levine, but the boys at 2K Marin may have managed to top the amazing story set forth in the original Bioshock.  In the first Bioshock, one of the major premises of the game revolves around the question of, “Why am I doing this?”  (And I’m hoping at least someone answered, “A man chooses, a slave obeys”).  The original Bioshock is brilliant science fiction populated by a colorful rotating sideshow of psychotic freaks.  But it missed a bit of the human element.  In Bioshock2 you know immediately who you are (in a basic sense), what you must do, and crucially why you must do it.  This opens up the opportunity for a more humanist approach to Rapture, being that the resolution of this tension allows for huge opportunities in characterization.  And Bioshock 2 seizes upon that opportunity in spades.  In the first game I was purely vested in the mystery itself which was great, but in this game I was actually attached to the characters as well.  This manages to add some emotional heft to the story which I felt was missing a bit in the first game.  (In truth this is probably helped by the fact that I myself am a parent, and the central themes of Bioshock 2 revolve heavily around what it means to be a parent … err … Daddy)So how’s the gameplay?  Well a lot like the first game, the difficulty curve here is a bit frontloaded.  As you gain plasmids, tonics, and weapons upgrades the game becomes significantly easier.  In some ways this is a bit unfortunate at least insofar as it would have been nice to feel that rush of badassery immediately upon stepping into the brass boots of a Big Daddy.  As it is you start off a bit weak and underpowered, slowly growing into your role as a walking fortress.  And that’s fine really.  It wouldn’t be super-fun or challenging if you started out as the biggest badass in Rapture.  Just as in the first game, Bioshock 2 really finds its groove when you start gaining power-ups to assist you in your endeavor, and it’s at this point that the gameplay absolutely shines.  It’s still an absolute blast to figure out interesting and advantageous combinations of plasmids, tonics, and weapon upgrades in order to rain death upon the doomed denizens of Rapture. There was one element of the first game that I did miss in Bioshock 2 which was the open world component.  In the original Bioshock  you felt the massiveness of Rapture in that you could travel from one end of the city to the other if you were so inclined.  In Bioshock 2 your experience is firmly divided into a level-based structure.  There are plot devices in place to help make some sense out of this particular element, but it warrants a mention.  To say that the game plays on rails is an understatement, being that your conveyance between levels for half the game is in fact a train.  It’s a minor thing, but I certainly would have loved to have the ability to return to previous levels for more in-depth exploration.  Oddly I also found some issue with repetitive tasks in the game, which I feel is also partly related to its strictly structured levels.  The way in which you’re tasked with the repetitive task(s) of rescuing a Little Sister, gathering Adam, dealing with the Little Sister, fighting Big Sister, wash, rinse, repeat … starts to feel a bit grind-y by the end of it.  It also impacts the pacing of the story a bit.  I think an open world setting might have relieved this issue somewhat in that it would have been nice to set my own agenda for handling the Little/Big sisters rather than being forced to handle everything in a level before moving onto the next without hope for return.  Once again this is a small issue in the grand scheme of things, but one that definitely became noticeable to me.  Luckily the combat allows for so much creativity and improvisation that this cycle rarely becomes a dreaded chore (despite my comments on grinding).So there you have it.  I must say that after two games of being trapped at the bottom of the ocean with the worst sort of abominations imaginable, I’m looking forward to taking my Bioshock experience to the sky in Bioshock Infinite, drifting through the clouds … with the worst sort of abominations imaginable. At any rate I found Bioshock 2 to be an excellent game particularly suited for fans of dark science fiction and horror, as well as anyone that enjoys story driven first person shooters.

												This game picks up sorta how the first Bioshock left off, you play as a Big Daddy, all big, all oafy and loud.  For fun make sure to play the game on the Hardest Difficulty, anything less and its just too easy.  This game is much shorter than the original but the pace feels good, it never drags, so dont let the length fool you.  The games mechanics are not as fun as the original.  Playing up until Dionysus Park a player can survive if they use resources carefully practicing ammo conservation, but on the Dionysus park level it all falls apart.  Enemies respawn real, real, fast.  Often times an enemy is killed then you walk around the corner and the same enemy respawns so fast and is shooting you in the back.  This is a HUGE problem because enemies dont always carry money to buy more ammo or supplies.  The lack of ammo or money to buy things is where the game breaks down due to this.  This broken gameplay of the weapons running out of ammo way to fast is compensated for by placing vending machines every 15 feet it feels like.  This could have been done less if either ammo was cheaper, or players could carry more ammo.  Being a big Daddy should be all about using the drill, but the drill requires fuel, fuel that evaporates way to fast even after upgrades making those vending machines every 10 feet useful.  The gameplay feels broken spending the whole game going to vending machines, the fuel should have lasted longer or there shoulda been an infinite fuel upgrade for the drill since its kind of the trademark big daddy weapon.  Hypnotize 3 is kinda useless, it lets you hypnotize big daddies which lasts for about ten seconds and worse if they throw a turret hypnotized or not it attacks you.  A good story and a fun game, def a must for bioshock fans.  Kinda thought this would suck and its nice that it isnt too bad.Rating:  7/10  Value:  $7.99

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												BioShock 2 suffers a curse that riddles many first sequels: being awkwardly hammered in between an absolute storm of a debut and an absolute killer of a third game. BioShock 2 is the disappointing middle child of the BioShock franchise, a product of a schism in 2K's original BioShock development team, bowing under the pressure of following up a global phenomenon in gaming and coming unfortunately before the series has decided what it actually is. However, in order to discover that, BioShock 2 had to exist.But there's more to it than that - just being a catalyst for BioShock Infinite's success. Although quite lacking in any rigid sort of philosophy, unlike BioShock which revels in it's nihilism and investigation of the perception of ethics, BioShock 2 works hard to reiterate the series' strengths. What it focusses on is everything but the original's cognitive plot, you get graphics, rich world, terror, heart-in-mouth action and an occassional tug on the old heartstrings. The opening movie and introductory level are superb, not matching the iconic opening of BioShock, but that is not an easily done thing by any game. The story and script are not stupid by any means and the game is not bad either. In actual fact it is quite fun playing as a Big Daddy but not as fun as you'd think. If it had gone all out in the brutality that Big Daddy's are known for, fast-paced chaos, carnage and bloodlust, it might have warmed me to it a little more. BioShock 2 however stays safe and tows that line between smart story and brutal, unflinching bad-a*sery, and we are instead given many sequences of wave upon wave of enemy with mines and traps and the occassional drill and plasmid.Still, it was good enough to make me happy as a BioShock entry and it was more than worthy of its namesake. Rapture, as always, is a pleasure to wander around and there is much that is new and much to be discovered. Despite the player character being hard as nails and heavily armoured, the game stays suspenseful throughout and the battles with Big Sisters are always huge slug-matches on the scale of King-Kong vs. Godzilla.Job's a good'n as we say in the UK.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												A dying father, a sinking city, and a utopian ideal gone horribly wrong. This is BioShock 2 at its center. After a brief, violent glimpse into Rapture before its fall from capitalist glory, players are sunk into the boots of Subject Delta, a big daddy with a bone to pick with the leader of Rapture's newly-mended society, the Rapture Family. The gameplay still has that zap-and-whack feel that gave the first BioShock's combat so much appeal. The blood on the walls and viewable acts of brutality also remind the player where they are: Rapture.In Delta's hunt for his Little Sister, he'll run into some familiar faces, and new ones. Tenenbaum has returned to this leaky ship, Ryan's posthumous voice is audible via recordings, and even Dr. Suchong and his grisly fate come to light. A whole host of new characters awaits Delta here, each of them interesting and memorable. Seldom are new Plasmids, but old weapons have been repurposed (and in some cases, replaced) for use by the protagonist Big Daddy. Deliberating over a Little Sister's fate is just as agonizing as before (even moreso, considering the player's role as a Protector), and pulling off a perfect plasmid-weapon combo is still a very, very satisfying experience. If you liked BioShock 1, you'll find nothing wrong with BioShock 2.Never before has bashing a Splicer's head in been so fun.

												I've yet to start playing/finish Bioshock: Infinite, but this may give me better judgement.I found Bioshock 2 to be even better than Bioshock 1. I do not know why, but I am not downgrading Bioshock 1. They are both equally amazing and cannot be purchased singularly without the other. One must also play Bioshock 1 FIRST in order to experience everything correctly.It's been a while since I last played it, but I am writing this review right now because I feel it deserves one. I played the fatherly daddy side of the story, rescuing each and every little sister. Multiple pathways and endings through the story mean easy replayability, and it does that well. I also appreciate how you have the choice of killing a character in the plot or not, directing the pathway in the way you wish, and giving that wonderous illusion of choice that many of us crave in a mostly linear game.The combat and entire "get little sister and get moar adam" can become repetitive, but that is only what I feel. Out of the weapons, each one can have an equal chance at being used as a main weapon, switching every once in a while for lack of ammo or to deal with a specific enemy, if that is your style of fighting--choosing a single weapon to specialize in or just swapping back and forth from time to time. I like the upgrading system; each upgrade is farily visible once you put it into use, and I never felt dissatisfaction at the upgrade I chose to fit my style of combat. The customizability makes this game very flexible for a large audience. I played on easy difficulty, though, as I do not own the most beefy computer.One thing I particularly liked about the game was the Big Sisters. I like how few times they are encountered, which keeps their appearance and deadliness fresh. Though one point became a bit boring, it was probably just my fault. I absolutely love the noises she makes before she appears, too.The music and atmostphere is quite attractive. I may even say slightly better if not noticeably better than the first Bioshock game.In conclusion, it IS worth the money, but don't be stupid. One has to play these games in order... BioShock, BioShock 2, and finally BioShock: Infinite, if one wishes to. Maybe the Burial At Sea DLC after that, if you want. The Life-Electrifying universe is pretty interesting and fun. If you ever plan to play the first two BioShock games, make sure to do so. If you do not, feel free to play Infinite as it is.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Playing video games for the first time long after their release is not always a bad thing. Indeed it enables us to see how they endure the test of time. And only true jewels can stand it. What about Bioshock II ? As I had been blown away after playing the first opus, I expected a lot from this sequel. And so did many Bioshock fans. Here's my review :(See rating at the end of the review)____________________________GAMEPLAY: Quite similar to what we experienced in the first game. The gameplay is really focused on immersive and explosive fighting sequences. The difference with the first opus is that there's no real final boss but very often the player is opposing big waves of ennemies. Hopefully it is possible to prepare your defense by setting traps and mines, hacking security cameras and turrets. But if you want to collect all the Adam, these defensive fights become too repetitive. On a more positive note, some new weapons add more fun to the gameplay. I really enjoyed playing with the drill and the spear gun. Moreover, it's really interesting to combine different weapon's and plasmid's attacks. I liked the fact, that as a Big Daddy you really feel the strength and the weight of your character. There are also different levels of difficulty that you may choose depending on your experience in FPS games. So don't worry if you're not used to this type of game. I'm not, but I still truly enjoyed playing it.VISUALS, MUSIC & ATMOSPHERE: That's why so many people love the Bioshock saga : a deep immersion into an equally beautiful and horrific world. Of course, I already knew how Rapture looked like but I was still surprised by the beauty of the scenery. And even if the game engine is getting older, the esthetic of this chaotic city is still mind-blowing. The new developers have even got further with more cutscenes and submarine exploration that offers quiet and contemplative moments between the fighting sequences. I also have to praise the soundtrack, the voice-acting and the sound effects that are even better than in the first Bioshock.STORY: In this sequel, which occurs ten years after the events of the first game, we play in this sequel a reborn Big Daddy who's trying to get back to his little sister. Our quest offers us the possibility to explore many new places and to meet new cheracters. The most interesting ones are the utopist Sofia Lamb and the opportunist Sinclair who take the roles of Ryan and Atlas in the antagonist-protagonist pattern. Because we are more familiar with Rapture and it's doom, we are less surprised by the wickedness of its inhabitants but there are still some strong revelations. Many elements of the story are smartly scattered in the Audio Diaries that the player finds on its way. And as we move towards the end of the game, the story becomes more and more intense. To me, three of the four different endings are a bit overdramatic but they still have a great theatrical effect. LENGTH: It takes around 10 hours to finish the game. More than that if you don't use the quest arrow. There's four different endings that you can experience depending of your choices, but because the game is very scripted I wouldn't do it all over again. ____________________________  Gameplay 4.5/6   Visuals, music and atmosphere 6/6   Story 4/6   Length 2/2   - -   Global Rating 16.5/20 Even if we are familiar with Rapture, it is still a great pleasure to explore this submarine terrifying world. Bioshock II is not disappointing at all in terms of visual design and atmosphere. However, this sequel is bit more focused on action than on the story. As a result, the gameplay is more entertaining but the story lacks originality.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												A sequel worthy of its precedessor.Bioshock 2 makes you jump right into the known an deep setting with familiar set of mechanics that went through slight alterations and refreshement; most noticeable with plasmids that suddenly became a much more interesting and versatile tool that doesn't force you to stop gunning. A change needed for the more action-y nature of the game when compared to the original Bioshock.While the gameplay feels very familiar, the storytelling isn't. The difference comes from the fact that the first game was all about introducing the player to Rapture and telling him the story of it. What was driving us all was the discovery, walking through the city that fell from its glory and plunged into darkness. That, and a very well constructed plot with just the right amount of surprises.You won't find that in the sequel - we know the place, we know the story. The plot got much simpler. What is it about, then? Feelings. Bioshock made you listen to the tale, yet stay a bit to the side. Bioshock 2, on the other hand, sacrifices some of it to make you feel and experience the Rapture as  Big Daddy. It's pulled off very well, and keeps the game on high level even if it is nto married to the same idea as the original. Gathering, protecting, curing, harvesting - it all feels more personal now. Same how it is for all the encounters with the 'main NPCs', which you can kill or spare. They all are relevant to who you play. You are not a 'stranger', but a part of the city. This aspect, and the general attitude of resorting to showing instead of telling gives this one a unique charm.

Posted: April 11, 2014
												I've yet to start playing/finish Bioshock: Infinite, but this may give me better judgement.I found Bioshock 2 to be even better than Bioshock 1. I do not know why, but I am not downgrading Bioshock 1. They are both equally amazing and cannot be purchased singularly without the other. One must also play Bioshock 1 FIRST in order to experience everything correctly.It's been a while since I last played it, but I am writing this review right now because I feel it deserves one. I played the fatherly daddy side of the story, rescuing each and every little sister. Multiple pathways and endings through the story mean easy replayability, and it does that well. I also appreciate how you have the choice of killing a character in the plot or not, directing the pathway in the way you wish, and giving that wonderous illusion of choice that many of us crave in a mostly linear game.The combat and entire "get little sister and get moar adam" can become repetitive, but that is only what I feel. Out of the weapons, each one can have an equal chance at being used as a main weapon, switching every once in a while for lack of ammo or to deal with a specific enemy, if that is your style of fighting--choosing a single weapon to specialize in or just swapping back and forth from time to time. I like the upgrading system; each upgrade is farily visible once you put it into use, and I never felt dissatisfaction at the upgrade I chose to fit my style of combat. The customizability makes this game very flexible for a large audience. I played on easy difficulty, though, as I do not own the most beefy computer.One thing I particularly liked about the game was the Big Sisters. I like how few times they are encountered, which keeps their appearance and deadliness fresh. Though one point became a bit boring, it was probably just my fault. I absolutely love the noises she makes before she appears, too.The music and atmostphere is quite attractive. I may even say slightly better if not noticeably better than the first Bioshock game.In conclusion, it IS worth the money, but don't be stupid. One has to play these games in order... BioShock, BioShock 2, and finally BioShock: Infinite, if one wishes to. Maybe the Burial At Sea DLC after that, if you want. The Life-Electrifying universe is pretty interesting and fun. If you ever plan to play the first two BioShock games, make sure to do so. If you do not, feel free to play Infinite as it is.

Posted: December 7, 2016
												So, first game review ever. I also own the first Bioshock, but can't review it because I didn't get it from Steam. But I digress. This game is the perfect followup to the first Bioshock. My first playthrough was on hard, and it makes the struggle through Rapture a constant war and bloodbath that is intense and challenging, even as a powerful Big Daddy. The new weapons really changed things up, while keeping and improving the original plasmids. Combat flows more naturally, since you don't have to switch betweens weapons and plasmids but can use them simultaneously. Now, the setting. Instead of an objectivistic society, now it is collectivist, striving for a disolving of the individual into "the family." I can't say too much about the plot without spoilers, but Big Daddies always have a Little Sister, and you are no exception. The story is strong, I think stronger than most give it credit for. It is good in its own right, but everyone (naturally) compares it to the first game, which has an exceptionally good story. Crashing? I play on Mac (yes, it actually runs on Mac). And actually, it crashes only rarely, and no problem with my save files. Mostly, it has crashed in the Protector Trials, but even then, only occasionally. With lots to explore, easter eggs that can almost make ya weep, combat that can feel totally awesome (turning yourself into a flamethrower is a real joy), and deep philosophical and moral questions at its heart, this game is excellent and I highly recommend it, even if you don't have the first game. That being said, get the first game. It's a masterpiece.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												So, you know that BioShock game, right? How it had a really good story, with neat plottwists, neat underwater world inspired heavily by Art Deco, and lackluster gameplay?You can't say anything about BioShock 2 without comparing it to the first one. BioShock 2 was an improvement in gameplay, that's for sure. Plasmid in one hand, gun in the other made a fine combination and killing was finally... well, fun. Gene Tonics added another layer of depth, even though at the end you can easily buy all the slots and fill them with the best tonics. Also, you get to be a Big Daddy, finally. After playing the first one, almost every player had this thought, how nice would be to play as one. So you get a drill and a rivet gun. Didn't change much in gameplay, but is neat.Can't forget about hacking though. First game had this water flowing in pipes minigame, thought it was nice, and a bit of a challenge. In the second game, they possibly decided it was too hard for consoles and replaced it with "click at the right moment" minigame. Pathetic. Boring. Click, click, click. Auto-hack darts help with that a bit, but still it left me with a bad taste in my mouth.Enemies. The main issue I had with the first game is in here too - splicers are supposed to have some personality, with small talk in some moments of the game, but they are still mindless and not challenging at all, just bullet sponges. Their quantity doesn't help with it - in my opinion, in such a game killing a person should make you feel bad at least a bit. I guess making them smarter and use elaborate tactics was too hard, so they just blamed splicing for messing with their heads.And the last thing - story. We all know it's weak. Has some problems. Disappearing (Tenenbaum?) and appearing for no reason characters make little sense. Main enemy is a woman that somehow gained followers that holds a teenage girl hostage. Her motivations are unclear, just like her modus operandi. Somehow she knows all and does nothing else, but monitors my movements. Sends me propaganda messages that are sure not to work. There's no plottwist or anything to make it better. Smaller bosses stories were much better. Grace had a solid story, Stanley did some weird stuff (but still better than Lamb), and Alexander had the best level. So, the story was far worse than in the first game. Good thing to note.But you know what? Story was definitely fixed in Minerva's Den. This DLC makes the entire game worth it, even though you have to play through the entire basic game to undersand it all. I know, it has backtracking, and hacking/enemies issues weren't resolved, but it's good even then.Even without the free DLC, I would recommend the game. It's not perfect, has some flaws, but you can't say it's bad or mediocre either.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												A dying father, a sinking city, and a utopian ideal gone horribly wrong. This is BioShock 2 at its center. After a brief, violent glimpse into Rapture before its fall from capitalist glory, players are sunk into the boots of Subject Delta, a big daddy with a bone to pick with the leader of Rapture's newly-mended society, the Rapture Family. The gameplay still has that zap-and-whack feel that gave the first BioShock's combat so much appeal. The blood on the walls and viewable acts of brutality also remind the player where they are: Rapture.In Delta's hunt for his Little Sister, he'll run into some familiar faces, and new ones. Tenenbaum has returned to this leaky ship, Ryan's posthumous voice is audible via recordings, and even Dr. Suchong and his grisly fate come to light. A whole host of new characters awaits Delta here, each of them interesting and memorable. Seldom are new Plasmids, but old weapons have been repurposed (and in some cases, replaced) for use by the protagonist Big Daddy. Deliberating over a Little Sister's fate is just as agonizing as before (even moreso, considering the player's role as a Protector), and pulling off a perfect plasmid-weapon combo is still a very, very satisfying experience. If you liked BioShock 1, you'll find nothing wrong with BioShock 2.Never before has bashing a Splicer's head in been so fun.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I prefer Bioshock 2 to the first game.The story is much tighter this time around, and doesn't suffer from all of the third act problems that the first game does. It develops its characters, themes, and setting much more naturally. Sophia Lamb is a great antagonist for the story and her worldview and history inside Rapture not only build her character, but develop Rapture and it's inhabitants--Rapture feels like a place people actually lived in. Motivations are still complex, but I found that they were clearer than the majority of those in the first game. The game also does a better job of weaving the choices you make in the game into the narrative. I found myself a lot more emotionally invested in the story of Bioshock 2.The gameplay is more intuitive and the plasmid/gene tonic/weapons upgrade system has a better balance. For example, the oddly redundant Chemical Thrower is gone, and it's abilities have been integrated into the plasmids. In Bioshock 1, there were a series of weapon upgrade stations scattered across the map offering two upgrades per weapon. In Bioshock 2, each weapon gets a third upgrade that unlocks after unlocking the two previous upgrades. The catch is that there are far less upgrade stations across the game, so you have to think more carefully about what you choose to upgrade. No longer requiring the player to choose between having a plasmid or weapon equipped makes a big difference in developing strategy for new areas.Graphically it holds up better, things are sharper and it looks like the textures have a higher resolution (or are simply optimized better). There are other small details that have been altered slightly from the first game but make a noticeable difference. The little sisters don't tiptoe the line near uncanny valley anymore and actually sound like children. There's more variety in the audio diaries you can find. Hacking is no longer a frustrating minigame. Colors are used in the art direction to greater effect be it the red glow of the Big Sisters or the pinks, blues and greens of sea life encroaching on Rapture. Just small things like this.Additionally, Minerva's Den is a great short story and DLC with its own unique gameplay mechanics. It is also worth picking up.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Despite what's often said of this game, it's a great one. Interestingly, in the absence of Ken Levine, it really points out his abilities and flaws.Expect a fairly simple, but quite effective story. There really aren't any plot twists, and evevrything pans out fairly nicely. But that doesn't matter, because the artists here masterfully constructs is so that you'd feel the full emotional impact all the same.What not to expect? Do not be awed. It is not an "exceptional" game in the conventional sense. Ken has a way with pivotal "moments" which this game lacks. There's nothing amazing in here at all, which is a shame. But Bioshock 2 is more than sum of all its part. Even the very predictable ending pays dividends, due to how well the whole thing has been setup. This isn't a game to make you awed and appalled like the original Bioshock, or pondering and thoughtful like Bioshock Infinite. I feel it's more of a sci-fi melodrama, and you'll find your sympathy swinging along with the main characters. Unlike the other Bioshock's the ending really feels rewarding.Gameplay itself is not special. At least you can use both Plasmids and guns at the same time, and you also get a melee attack as well. Apart from a few new Plasmids to play around with, you'll be here for the same sort of thing as you had with the other games. I can't comment much on the multiplayer. There are no servers, and you'll be playing on listen servers, i.e. other people's PC, so expect lag. I live too far away from the continents to play this very well, so I can't give a good review of that. Anyway, it's a good buy, and I wholly recommend this to anyone who has 10 hours to spare.

												So, first game review ever. I also own the first Bioshock, but can't review it because I didn't get it from Steam. But I digress. This game is the perfect followup to the first Bioshock. My first playthrough was on hard, and it makes the struggle through Rapture a constant war and bloodbath that is intense and challenging, even as a powerful Big Daddy. The new weapons really changed things up, while keeping and improving the original plasmids. Combat flows more naturally, since you don't have to switch betweens weapons and plasmids but can use them simultaneously. Now, the setting. Instead of an objectivistic society, now it is collectivist, striving for a disolving of the individual into "the family." I can't say too much about the plot without spoilers, but Big Daddies always have a Little Sister, and you are no exception. The story is strong, I think stronger than most give it credit for. It is good in its own right, but everyone (naturally) compares it to the first game, which has an exceptionally good story. Crashing? I play on Mac (yes, it actually runs on Mac). And actually, it crashes only rarely, and no problem with my save files. Mostly, it has crashed in the Protector Trials, but even then, only occasionally. With lots to explore, easter eggs that can almost make ya weep, combat that can feel totally awesome (turning yourself into a flamethrower is a real joy), and deep philosophical and moral questions at its heart, this game is excellent and I highly recommend it, even if you don't have the first game. That being said, get the first game. It's a masterpiece.

												So, you know that BioShock game, right? How it had a really good story, with neat plottwists, neat underwater world inspired heavily by Art Deco, and lackluster gameplay?You can't say anything about BioShock 2 without comparing it to the first one. BioShock 2 was an improvement in gameplay, that's for sure. Plasmid in one hand, gun in the other made a fine combination and killing was finally... well, fun. Gene Tonics added another layer of depth, even though at the end you can easily buy all the slots and fill them with the best tonics. Also, you get to be a Big Daddy, finally. After playing the first one, almost every player had this thought, how nice would be to play as one. So you get a drill and a rivet gun. Didn't change much in gameplay, but is neat.Can't forget about hacking though. First game had this water flowing in pipes minigame, thought it was nice, and a bit of a challenge. In the second game, they possibly decided it was too hard for consoles and replaced it with "click at the right moment" minigame. Pathetic. Boring. Click, click, click. Auto-hack darts help with that a bit, but still it left me with a bad taste in my mouth.Enemies. The main issue I had with the first game is in here too - splicers are supposed to have some personality, with small talk in some moments of the game, but they are still mindless and not challenging at all, just bullet sponges. Their quantity doesn't help with it - in my opinion, in such a game killing a person should make you feel bad at least a bit. I guess making them smarter and use elaborate tactics was too hard, so they just blamed splicing for messing with their heads.And the last thing - story. We all know it's weak. Has some problems. Disappearing (Tenenbaum?) and appearing for no reason characters make little sense. Main enemy is a woman that somehow gained followers that holds a teenage girl hostage. Her motivations are unclear, just like her modus operandi. Somehow she knows all and does nothing else, but monitors my movements. Sends me propaganda messages that are sure not to work. There's no plottwist or anything to make it better. Smaller bosses stories were much better. Grace had a solid story, Stanley did some weird stuff (but still better than Lamb), and Alexander had the best level. So, the story was far worse than in the first game. Good thing to note.But you know what? Story was definitely fixed in Minerva's Den. This DLC makes the entire game worth it, even though you have to play through the entire basic game to undersand it all. I know, it has backtracking, and hacking/enemies issues weren't resolved, but it's good even then.Even without the free DLC, I would recommend the game. It's not perfect, has some flaws, but you can't say it's bad or mediocre either.

												I've yet to start playing/finish Bioshock: Infinite, but this may give me better judgement.I found Bioshock 2 to be even better than Bioshock 1. I do not know why, but I am not downgrading Bioshock 1. They are both equally amazing and cannot be purchased singularly without the other. One must also play Bioshock 1 FIRST in order to experience everything correctly.It's been a while since I last played it, but I am writing this review right now because I feel it deserves one. I played the fatherly daddy side of the story, rescuing each and every little sister. Multiple pathways and endings through the story mean easy replayability, and it does that well. I also appreciate how you have the choice of killing a character in the plot or not, directing the pathway in the way you wish, and giving that wonderous illusion of choice that many of us crave in a mostly linear game.The combat and entire "get little sister and get moar adam" can become repetitive, but that is only what I feel. Out of the weapons, each one can have an equal chance at being used as a main weapon, switching every once in a while for lack of ammo or to deal with a specific enemy, if that is your style of fighting--choosing a single weapon to specialize in or just swapping back and forth from time to time. I like the upgrading system; each upgrade is farily visible once you put it into use, and I never felt dissatisfaction at the upgrade I chose to fit my style of combat. The customizability makes this game very flexible for a large audience. I played on easy difficulty, though, as I do not own the most beefy computer.One thing I particularly liked about the game was the Big Sisters. I like how few times they are encountered, which keeps their appearance and deadliness fresh. Though one point became a bit boring, it was probably just my fault. I absolutely love the noises she makes before she appears, too.The music and atmostphere is quite attractive. I may even say slightly better if not noticeably better than the first Bioshock game.In conclusion, it IS worth the money, but don't be stupid. One has to play these games in order... BioShock, BioShock 2, and finally BioShock: Infinite, if one wishes to. Maybe the Burial At Sea DLC after that, if you want. The Life-Electrifying universe is pretty interesting and fun. If you ever plan to play the first two BioShock games, make sure to do so. If you do not, feel free to play Infinite as it is.
