content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
This is a long review so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend BioShock 2 skip to Results and read from there.2K Games does it again with a beautiful story, fantastic gameplay, and wonderful internal environment. BioShock 2 has it all and pushes the greatness of the series to new heights.Story:Taking place after the original life has been brought back to the lost, but never forgotten city of Rapture. Professor Lamb has started working to bring young girls back down to the deep city and start cultivating Adam once again. Her idea of a utopia exists unlike Ryan’s which is based on uncontrolled capitalism Lambs is based on true altruism, the idea of the true utopia. You as one of the original Big Daddy’s have been brought back to life to save Eleanor, your Little Sister from a fate worse than death. Will you be able to make it in time?Campaign:There are nine levels: Adonis Luxury Resort, Atlantic Express, Ryan Amusements, Pauper’s Drop, Siren Alley, Dionysus Park, Fontaine Futuristics, Outer Persephone, and Inner Persephone. The levels in this campaign vary in length drastically, some of them being relatively short while others are overly massive. You have varying objectives in each area: find items, fight bosses, activate switches, find little sisters, etc. These keep the campaign interesting and each area has its own spin on how it wants you to play. The campaign is well laid out and each area has its own twists that make it unique. Gameplay:The game plays differently than the original, as you are no longer a mere mortal but rather one of the machines you fought so hard to defeat. You wield all weapons single handedly allowing you to equip plasmids in your other hand. This way you can shoot a gun as well as light a foe on fire, personally I was so used to the first one I forgot half the time I could do this. When I finally realized I still found myself not using it as the menu interface to change between plasmids was not as dynamic. This games combat realistically was drastically improved; no longer did you need to keep pulling out the camera during battle to get the best shot, instead you just clicked and it recorded while you were in combat giving you a score for the battle. The remote hacking tool allows you to actually hack cameras, which you could do in the first one but was very tricky as they would almost always detect you before you started the hack. Plus the wrench was changed to a drill which had multiple attack types making it more dynamic. In BioShock I actually used the Wrench all game, so I decided to only use ranged weapons this time round. There are three key combat elements in this game: Weapons, Plasmids (like spells), and tonics (like buffs). The weapons, plasmids, and tonics really allow you to customize your play style. By choosing specific tonics in combination with weapon choose and plasmid choice you can decide if you want to be a melee master, a total hacker, or gunning madman. Plus each weapon, plasmid, and tonic has upgraded versions which make them even more effective and variable. Minerva’s Den:I wasn't sure about Minerva's Den, usually DLC campaigns are just extra levels and lose the elements that make a game great. Minerva's Den was the complete opposite, in fact this DLC story rivals that of the original. There are three levels: Minerva's Den, Operations, and The Thinker. The first two levels are exceptionally large and have many missions/puzzles invovled and the final level is a boss fight. This DLC adds an exceptional amount of depth including a new weapon (Ion Laser) a new Plamid (Gravity Well), two new tonics, and four new enemies. This is an amazing new campaign which offers a brilliant story and fantastic new elements to the BioShock series. Results:BioShock 2 is an amazing game; although, it doesn’t stand up to the story of the original it still provides an amazing play-through. The story itself is relatively well written, and in comparison to non-BioShock games is actually quite brilliant. The combat is fun and rather in-depth with each weapon having three ammo types including the melee tool gives a huge variety to your combat style. You can even customize your tonics and plasmids to enforce the type of gameplay you desire. BioShock really is the FPS for anyone looking for a great story, invigorating combat, epic boss battles, and cool puzzles. I would recommend this game at full price, but if you’re frugal like me and only buy games on sale then wait as anything below its normal price is a steal. Pros:+Fantastic story+Beautiful game environment+Loads of weapons, with different ammo types+Many plasmids (spells) to choose from with upgraded levels+Loads of tonics (passives) to equip which customize your gameplay experience+Three difficulty settings, for all levels of gamers to enjoy.+New dynamic to the BioShock series revealing the inner sanctum of the Big Daddy.+Offers DLC to extend the experience.Cons:-The game allows you to set the difficulty in the menu. I started the game on “Hard” and somehow it dropped to “Medium” at some point. I didn’t notice until a hint popped up about 1/3 the way through when I thought to myself how easy the game was. I bumped it up again to “Hard” and kept a check on it for the rest of the campaign, but this change resulted in my not being able to get the “Against All Odds” achievement. -The game would crash randomly for no reason, I did a verify integrity check but it said the game was fine. In turn I started saving every five minutes so I wouldn’t lose much if it crashed.

												The "best"/least mediocre Bioshock game. I actually kinda liked this one.The story and themes try to copy Bioshock 1 but it kind of ends up being a blander copy in that regard. But screw that! It actually manages to be fun throughout the whole game (unlike Bioshock) and the story isn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ multi-dimension quantum magic pretentious hipster drivel (unlike Infinite). Basically, you're one of the first Big Daddies, and part of Rapture's Splicers have turned, in the 8 years since the first game, into a "Family" led by Female Andrew Ryan with a different philosophy, aka, Sofia Lamb. Your daughter is being controlled by her to be the Ultimate Citizen, and you want to get her back, as a Big Daddy would. There are twice as much endings this time (I didn't check the differences between them because I can't be arsed to), and the difference between these, besides harvesting or rescuing Little SIsters, is that they also depend on certain characters that you save. Or not. Bascially, instead of having 1 choice, you have 4.Gunplay is sort of between Bioshock (mediocre) and Infinite (less mediocre), and though it is slightly more linear than Bioshock at times, it doesn't waste hours of your time with backtracking (hence the shorter gameplay time even though I explored through most nooks and crannies) and the guns are slightly more original than Infinite's: Instead of the WW1 weaponry, you have the Big Daddy's Rivet Gun, a sort of minigun instead of that♥♥♥♥♥♥Tommy Gun from BS1, a harpoon launcher, a one-handed shotgun and Bioshock1's grenade launcher. You can also dual-wield plasmids, and the upgrades for both plasmids and weaponry are also more original than the 2 other Bioshcok games. Compared to both Ken Levine's Bioshocks, the game also has a lot less full of HP-bloated bullet sponges (though it gets more offensive in this regard towards the last 2 or 3 levels).Bioshock's Little SIster gameplay of harvesting or rescuing Little Sisters after fighting disgustingly HP-bloated enemies turns into adopting or harvesting. If you adopt them (You're a Big Daddy in this game, forgot to mention that) You can reenact the worst level of the first game where you go around letting them harvest ADAM (the magical space-slug chemical that allows you to upgrade your magic powers aka Plasmids) while playing tower defense.You only have to do this once though (for tutorial purposes *sigh*) and in later times you can just send them to the nearest vent and rescue or harvest them. The Big Daddies are not bullet sponges anymore because you have more powerful weaponry (now, there are Brute Splicers for whatever reason, which take up the seat of annoying bullet sponge that charges at you.) content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												TLDR: An enjoyable follow-up to the first game continues the story of Rapture with a new protagonist, a new conflicted (kind of) big boss and more gene splicing action. This time around you have some moral decision making to do, and your actions affect the game’s ending.If you’ve played the first Bioshock game, you’ll remember that in the mid 1900’s the world’s top minds secretly worked together to build the underwater city of Rapture, and created what they thought was the ultimate utopia, free of government and religion. Instead they were ruled by the free market and meritocracy, so everyone makes money based on being good at something. In Bioshock 2, you learn that the pressures of this “perfect world” started to get to the citizens (especially the poor), and a psychiatrist was brought in to help people deal with the stresses of pure competition. Unfortunately, the psychiatrist Sofia Lamb had her own agenda, and saw the opportunity to create a true Utopia in Rapture through the use of Adam. Adam is a genetic material that can be used to create “plasmids” for artificial evolution through gene splicing. It doesn’t just give people super powers though, apparently it can be used to transfer the memories of the users to certain prepared users (Little Sisters). Little Sisters are orphaned girls who have been kidnapped and turned into walking “Adam factories” who can later be harvested for their gooey Adam. The Little Sisters are guarded by Big Daddies, brainwashed people in armored diving gear who are psychically linked to their Little Sisters and guard them from any threat.In Bioshock 2, you play a Big Daddy, though the gameplay is nearly the same as in the first game (where you were a human). It’s still a First Person Shooter and the weapons are mostly the same as well. There’s been a refinement to the plasmid system where you’re basically dual wielding now (plasmid in one hand and gun in the other). In the first game you had to switch between gun and plasmid. A big change is that because you’re a Big Daddy, you do a bunch of mini escort missions where you guard Little Sisters as they gather their Adam. Just like in the first game, you have a huge variety of weapon ammo types and plasmid types to help you survive, though you might notice that the game is more difficult this time around. It seems like you take more damage in Bioshock 2 than in the first game.Pros:+The story is good though it’s a little difficult to figure out what the deal is with Sofia Lamb. How did she turn into such a ♥♥♥♥♥?+The game takes what is good about the first game and adds to it. I kind of liked the hacking mini game in the first game better though. There are more weapon types, more plasmids, and more enemies. The mini bosses in the first game were the Big Daddies, who are back, but now you have the Big Sisters to deal with as well and they’re twice as powerful. +The game has 6 different endings depending on the moral choices you make throughout, but they’re actually very close to each other. I’ve probably only seen 3 of them because I usually play games as a “good person” and had to go out of my way to make evil decisions. Cons:-People have told me that Bioshock 2 is the weakest in the Bioshock series and I can see their point. There really isn’t much more innovation and it’s kind of like a continuation of the first game in terms of technical improvement. Like with Saints Row 4, where people said it was almost a really long DLC for Saints Row 3.-There were some technical issues for me related to graphics. It seems to be a common occurrence based on what I found when googling for solutions. To keep the game from crashing, I had to change the display to Direct X 9.Overall, if you liked the first Bioshock, you’ll probably like Bioshock 2, though maybe not quite as much. The game takes about 10 hours to beat and is more than worth your time.  8.5/10

But screw that! It actually manages to be fun throughout the whole game (unlike Bioshock) and the story isn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ multi-dimension quantum magic pretentious hipster drivel (unlike Infinite). Basically, you're one of the first Big Daddies, and part of Rapture's Splicers have turned, in the 8 years since the first game, into a "Family" led by Female Andrew Ryan with a different philosophy, aka, Sofia Lamb. Your daughter is being controlled by her to be the Ultimate Citizen, and you want to get her back, as a Big Daddy would. There are twice as much endings this time (I didn't check the differences between them because I can't be arsed to), and the difference between these, besides harvesting or rescuing Little SIsters, is that they also depend on certain characters that you save. Or not. Bascially, instead of having 1 choice, you have 4.Gunplay is sort of between Bioshock (mediocre) and Infinite (less mediocre), and though it is slightly more linear than Bioshock at times, it doesn't waste hours of your time with backtracking (hence the shorter gameplay time even though I explored through most nooks and crannies) and the guns are slightly more original than Infinite's: Instead of the WW1 weaponry, you have the Big Daddy's Rivet Gun, a sort of minigun instead of that♥♥♥♥♥♥Tommy Gun from BS1, a harpoon launcher, a one-handed shotgun and Bioshock1's grenade launcher. You can also dual-wield plasmids, and the upgrades for both plasmids and weaponry are also more original than the 2 other Bioshcok games. Compared to both Ken Levine's Bioshocks, the game also has a lot less full of HP-bloated bullet sponges (though it gets more offensive in this regard towards the last 2 or 3 levels).Bioshock's Little SIster gameplay of harvesting or rescuing Little Sisters after fighting disgustingly HP-bloated enemies turns into adopting or harvesting. If you adopt them (You're a Big Daddy in this game, forgot to mention that) You can reenact the worst level of the first game where you go around letting them harvest ADAM (the magical space-slug chemical that allows you to upgrade your magic powers aka Plasmids) while playing tower defense.You only have to do this once though (for tutorial purposes *sigh*) and in later times you can just send them to the nearest vent and rescue or harvest them. The Big Daddies are not bullet sponges anymore because you have more powerful weaponry (now, there are Brute Splicers for whatever reason, which take up the seat of annoying bullet sponge that charges at you.) To keep a certain amount of dificulty in harvesting/rescuing Little Sisters (even though all difficulty in the Bioshock games is fake because you can just respawn with almost zero cost near where you "died"), at the end of the level, come Big Sisters to get the ADAM you got back. They are sort of a combination of Big Daddies (the charge at you) and Houdini and Spider Splicers (they jump around, and throw fireballs and whatever objects are in the vicinity, at you.) They are not complete bullet sponges, and are fairly fun to fight against.Overall, it's not really a great game, but it sure as hell is better than ♥♥♥♥ing Infinite. And the first game as well.

												The sequal to one of the best single-player shooters I have played. Bioshock 2 had some really awesome features but it fell short of one critical item. Story. It's story was not the best. It had its moments but it was not impressive. The graphics were definently improved. Gameplay was great but it had weak spots, Because you play as a Big Daddy, You gain access to a very powerful arsenal. Having that makes it seem to easy at times but also very satisfying. You also are able to still harvest/ rescue little sisters. When rescued you have the option to "adopt" them. This was a very neat feature because it allowed for more adam to be collected and a side event where you guarded her while she harvested. It made the player feel more attached or closer to the little sister. Bioshock 2 also added a new boss "The Big Sister". She was a very nimble close range character. She was able to collect adam and she could appear at random times. *minor spoiler alert* [/spoiler] The Big Sister was created to keep the little sister away from the big daddys, this was interesting because it gave the player a real reason to really kill her besides "shes hurting me I'll just hurt her back" [/spoiler] They also added new big daddys. All in all this was a good title for the gameplay but the story was definently not as good as the first or infinite. It's definently worth the 19.99 price tag it has.

												Big Sister knows bestBioshock was a wonderful game (5/5) and BIOSHOCK 2 is no less an achievement. 2K have taken all the elements that made the original so great and have tweaked them in all the right ways to make the second game even better than the first. TL;DRA continuation of a famous sci-fi FPS.+ Fascinating story+ Variety of tools of destruction (Spear Gun FTW!)+ Plasmids+ Atmosphere+ Graphics+ Soundtrack- Gathering ADAM gets old pretty quicklyREVIEWBioshock 2 is the sequel to the innovative sci-fi FPS. It continues the story of the underwater city of Rapture.Several years after the events of the first game, a prototype Big Daddy called Subject Delta is brought back to life in order to find and rescue Eleanor, a Little Sister whom he is bonded with, from the hands of the Rapture's new leader, Sofia Lamb. Sofia is a psychiatrist who believes that only by sacrificing our egos can we make the Earth a good place to live. That is a polar opposite of what Andrew Ryan stood for. Like in the predecessor, there are many voice recordings to be found. Moreover, the gloomy atmosphere of the desolated Rapture combined with the colourful water depths compliments the game perfectly.The gameplay has not changed much – the goal is to complete the given tasks and harvesting or rescuing Little Sisters. There are more enemies and they are a bit more challenging. Feminists have finally been heard and Now there is a female counterpart to the Big Daddies – the Big Mommas Sisters (as if the female leader was not enough...). Moreover, a new mechanic has been added – being a Big Daddy, the player can choose to "adopt" a Little Sister and make her gather ADAM from corpses. The procedure is similar to the good ol' King of the Hill mode – the player has to protect the child while she is harvesting the precious substance. However, it can get old pretty fast.Speaking of additions to the game, there are new weapons and plasmids. For instance, there is a spear gun which I have grown to love (probably more than I should...). In terms of new plasmids, Scout comes to mind. This power lets you deploy a ghost projection that can use plasmids or hack devices. Bioshock 2 supports a variety of playstyles which adds to the replay value. There also is a multiplayer mode.To conclude, Bioshock 2 is a worthy sequel to the original. The combination of the fascinating story, great graphics, and a variety of choices makes it a marvellous title. P.S. content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												I played this game on the 360 when it came out back in 2010. I blazed through it in one night, and revisited the multiplayer once or twice. As a result, I didn't remember much about it. I got into PC gaming a few months ago when I built my first rig, and have really enjoyed it. In the spirit of nostalgia, I bought the Bioshock double pack during an Amazon sale, curious how the games would look on my new machine. So, I embarked on a back-to-back Bioshock playthrough, and I wasn't disappointed. Though the first game is spectacular, and one of my favorites, I found that I enjoyed the sequel far more. I realize this is an unpopular opinion, but bear with me. The mechanics are far more refined and enjoyable compared to the original game. Allowing the player to wield weapons and plasmids simultaneously in particular really spices up the gameplay. All of the weapons are fun to use, notably the trap ammunition. I also felt that the story was much more engaging, and had me more invested than that of the first game. Though the 'WYK' twist is certainly one of the best moments in gaming, it is both the high point, and most memorable story element from the first game. In Bioshock 2, the narrative is woven in a much more consistent manner. Everything you do has purpose, driving you towards your end goal. I didn't get this same feeling in the first game - areas seemed strung together, giving it a more level-based feel.I could extoll the virtues of this game for many more paragraphs, but the only way to truly appreciate it is with first-hand experience. Don't be deterred by those who paint this game as the cash-in middle child of the franchise. Sure, it didn't inject the series with a bunch of new mechanics, but that's not what the development team set out to do. They did, however, deliver a solid game that is worthy to sit on the shelf (or desktop) beside its more well-received siblings.

Posted: August 12, 2014
												Let's just start with looking back to first Bioshock which was by the way great gaming experience for me. Splendid idea of underwater city Rapture built with vision of free mind for artist/scientists and other types of creative people that might get limited by their surroundings in world, but not in Rapture.As all previous utopistic societies that went straight into hell - new genetic improvements so called plasmids enhances your physical/psychical abilities in cost of ruining your body and mind (as drugs). But as every addict - you want more... but supplies are limited, so you start thinking about taking some from the others. In Rapture there were two major fractions - people listening to Andrew Ryan (man who built this "paradise") and Frank Fontaine(Ryans rival). After civil war, city was in ruins and people who survived this became weak-minded mutants (splicers) demanding ADAM (genetic material for plasmids).In Bioshock 2 not much really changes from that - except city is more ruined and remaining splicers are uglier and desperate more than ever. Story of Bioshock 2 happens many years after first Bioshock. Power vacuum was filled with new visionary - Sophia Lamb.You play as Big Daddy (subject Delta) whom was taken a little sister (Eleanor) years ago. You wake up revived by vita chamber years after death. And because you are genetically bounded with your little sister, you must find it or you'll die.Your journey begins here...I must say I enjoyed discovering new locations, newly refined plasmids, improved combat system (now you can hold plasmid and gun simultanously) and mainly fact being a big daddy, that giant monster in metal diving suit wearing drill, rivet gun and all...Unlike first Bioshock, this one experiments with multiplayer and I must say it ended half-way to success. It have same atmosphere as Bioshock 1, game modes are fun, gameplay is challenging and entertaining same time, you have a lot of singleplayer elements here (hacking turrets, vending machines etc.), but lack of dedicated servers is biggest problem here and no matter how good gameplay you can offer, absention of dedicated erver bound with horribly coded network code ruins everything.And I don't even mention GFWL and so called "DLCs" with overpowered third gun upgrades, new maps that you could play only if everyone owned that DLC (almost imposible) - I had to struggle with that until I stopped play it from frustration. Finally after some time GFWL closed (hurray for that) Bioshock was moved to Steam platform with all multiplayer expansions for free to all! So I could finally play some nice multiplayer... until people stopped play it so much, well at least I had some quality games before that.It's a must have for every Bioshock 1 fan, but I would recomment it for people who likes interesting FPS shooters with some STORY (not pointing at any bad-story games (lies... lies..))One of the best games I ever played and that is a truth.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Bioshock 2 is an older game now (nearly 4 years!) and has been reviewed many times; I'll repeat one thing that was common to a lot of those: If you liked Bioshock, you'll like Bioshock 2.  It doesn't have _quite_ as much impact as the former, largely due to the change of protagonist.  As Jack, even spliced up, you felt small.  Human.  Vulnerable.  There was a mile of freezing seawater between you and escape, and the lunatics had free run of the asylum... and drowning was something you would have no problem doing.  As Subject Delta (or, in Minerva's Den, Subject Sigma), you feel like a Big Daddy.  A little ponderous, but armoured, tough, and more than capable of beating a few splicers to death.The story isn't quite as brilliant either - in the first game, Rapture was new (to you), and everything was exploration of Andrew Ryan's ruined dream.  Well, in 2, Rapture is just as pretty, just as fascinating... but not quite as new.  There's a certain sense of familiarity for those who've played through the first game and spent quite a few hours in the slowly decaying city.  It's worth noting that as with the first game, the art assets for Bioshock 2 are stunning.  Post-apocalyptic art deco and water effects make for a feast for the eyes.Some of the new Plasmids (plus the ability to use guns and plasmids at the same time) make for some real fun, mechanically, and even if you're feeling like a nice, tough Big Daddy, the Splicers haven't been sitting still either.  There are some real challenges at the higher difficulty levels.Overall, if you don't have it, but have played Bioshock, get this game, and play it.  If you don't have it, and _haven't_ played Bioshock, get Bioshock.  Then get this game and play it. :)

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I had written a lengthy, verbose review for this game (before it was inexplicably lost), exploring the narrative genius of Irrational's Bioshock, and the monumental difficulty of crafting a sequel. Such a masterpiece was nearly impossible to follow up, but somehow, in some miraculous, ADAM-infused way, 2K Marin managed it. While the first game explored the downfall of objectivism, and the inner depravity of man, the sequel dives (literally) into the aftermath of the Randian utopia's fall, and the theocratic communism that replaces it. The viewpoints and goals of Bioshock 2's antagonist, Sofia Lamb, is diametrically opposed to those of Andrew Ryan (and Frank Fontaine), which lends this sequel a very different flavour. It remedies Bioshock's failings, however few, and improves upon one of the most versatile and satisfying gameplay systems ever concieved. Bioshock 2 is, truly, worth your time.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												I really enjoyed "Bioshock," it really was one of the best games ever made. So naturally, that meant I was looking forward to playing this game. And I was not disappointed. "Bioshock 2" really does manage to keep the fun of it's predecessor, and giving a good story to follow. Though at times, it felt like it was lacking. But I still played through it, and I got a satisfactory enjoyment out of it. I bought this game with "Bioshock" and "Bioshock Infinite", so after completing the first game, I jumped right in to this one.  The story is very heart wrenching, with an interesting theme, and it expands upon it's setting, while still maintaining the spirit of the first game.We return to Rapture in this game, eight years after the first game ended. And it looks worse for the wear. Having played the first game, I really felt some of the awe was gone from wanting to explore. But I still found it fun to see other places in Rapture that weren't in the first game, and I really enjoyed the aesthetics, how much of a novelty this city is. The game uses the same graphics from the first game, but it still keeps the setting looking very nice, and I liked how it incorporated underwater areas, which are very gorgeous to go through. The gameplay is relatively unchanged from the first game. This helps maintain the learning curve the first game had, making it easy for first-time and returning players to get into the game. I still enjoyed using the Plasmids, they're really nice. But I liked how you no longer had to switch from weapons to plasmids, as Subject Delta (the player character) can use both at the same time, which is a definite improvement. I also liked how you no longer needed to divide tonics into categories, giving you one full selection. Like in the first game, you could make Subject Delta your own character with your choice of Plasmids and Tonics to suit your own gameplay style. I tended to focus on hacking more, since I hacked a lot of stuff in this game.But what I really liked was that you were playing as a Big Daddy, allowing you to get a sense of what it's like being one. Whenever you adopt Little Sisters, you can either harvest them or take them with you to gather more ADAM or take them to an air vent and free them. However, the Little Sister defense got really repetitive for me, and more of an annoyance over time, but I really wanted that extra ADAM for more Plasmids and Tonics.The plot wasn't as predictable as I expected, and the game really turned up the morality to make it more meaningful in the long run. It still keeps it straightforward and never overcomplicates it with too much plot, like the first game. It no longer revolves around saving or harvesting Little Sisters. You encounter certain characters who have a connection to Subject Delta, and you get the choice to either kill them or let them live. This really affects how the final act of the game takes place. I also liked Eleanor Lamb, and her connection to Subject Delta in contrast to her connection to Sofia Lamb, giving a great theme of parents going to extreme lengths for their child's welfare. I really hated Sofia and her stupid ideas, and this game suceeds in the same place of making an extremely unlikable antagonist, it makes you keep going.I liked how they changed the hacking minigame, but it's still annoying, as you have to pay very close attention to the needle when it hits the right spot. The enemy variety is unchanged, but with the addition of the Brutes and Big Sisters. Both of them were extremely annoying, even after I got better weapons, plasmids, and ammo. But the Big Sisters, they add more of a risk to saving/harvesting the Little Sisters, and they make you really duck for cover before you fight them, so they do have a bit of a scare factor. And again, USE THE CAMERA! You'll need the research.I overall liked this game. It delivered what it promised, the setting still holds up, the gameplay is still easy to learn, and the plot is still kept pretty simple, and the morality is expanded upon to make it more meaningful. I was disappointed that the game didn't really have much else to offer, but it's still a good time. I intend to play this game again soon.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on March 16, 2010 Bioshock 2 is the full fledged sequel to Bioshock, although at times it feels more like an expansion pack to the original...Gameplay-The gameplay of Bioshock 2 is largely an improvement over the original, with the player taking on the role of a Big Daddy prototype instead of Jack. Prototype is the operative word here, however, as with the exception of having a drill and clunky sound effects when moving or jumping, you never really feel like a big daddy. Splicers can often cause you large amounts of damage with small arms or melee weapons in only a few hits, which is very similar to the first game. I understand why this choice was made, for balance purposes, and I actually largely agree with it, but the feeling of being a clunking metal behemoth is never really there.However, on an overall level, the sequel makes several key improvements. simultaneous usage of plasmids and weapons make combat much more fluid and satisfying, and the introduction of new enemies (alphas, brutes, big sisters) and the revamping of old ones (spider splicers, rumbler daddies) really contribute to this. Also, the game feels a good deal harder than the original without sacrificing the ability to make gameplay choices, and this is partially accomplished by upping the ante of combat. Where before you would only see 2-3 splicers an engagement, in Bioshock 2 it is not uncommon to engage a brute or two and 3-4 leadhead splicers in the same area.The adopt/save/harvest mechanic with the little sisters works very well, allowing you to kill big daddies as before, and choose whether to a) harvest them right away b) have them gather ADAM for you and then harvest them c) save them right away d) have them gather and then save them. Obviously the best choice either way is to have them harvest ADAM from special corpses in the level first to get more ADAM, but this adds a great deal of moral and gameplay depth to the little sister dynamic. Plus, having the little sister ride on your shoulders and comment on combat as you go along is at times hilarious, or just cute, and a little sad. A very nice touch. Messing with the little sisters angers the big sisters, who often come for you after you've dealt with most of the little sisters in the level. They serve as improvised and random boss-fights, and are most definitely a challenge. They add a new source of tension (and ADAM) to the Bioshock formula.Another gameplay change is the revamped Plasmid and Gene Tonic system. Plasmids at higher levels (2,3) have differentiated visual and gameplay effects, such as being able to charge up for more powerful attacks and shoot streams of elemental damage. They add a great deal of gameplay variety and re-playability. In addition, gene tonics are now all organized into one large slot, a welcome change, and some new ones have appeared that cover multiple effects, such as the elemental gene tonics. Finally, research remains useful but has been streamlined with a few minor tweaks.Finally, the much touted ocean underwater sequences remain a pretty but relatively gimmicky and useless area of gameplay, where you are basically placed in a tunnel from one airlock to another. They are incredibly atmospheric, but they serve very little gameplay purpose other than scrounging.Visuals-Bioshock 2 is the full fledged sequel to Bioshock, although visually speaking it feels more like an expansion pack to the original. The game runs on the same engine as the original from 2007, and while innovations have been made in art design and level design, the same graphics remain largely untouched. The same low-res textures and effects are intact, and with the exception of new plasmid effects and a few minor tweaks, the technical graphics remain the same as they were in 2007. This is very upsetting, but it is an industry wide trend, and consoles are almost entirely responsible. Therefore, Bioshock 2 will not be penalized too harshly.Artistically, the game does not disappoint, and the sound effects that accompany these new designs create a great atmosphere for the city of Rapture that feels fresh the second time around. New posters, new music, new character models, new weapons, and new effects.Story-In addition, the story, which has received some flak from Gamespot and other websites, is surprisingly good, and the audio diaries continue a wonderful trend from the first game that add a great deal of back story to Rapture and the tale of Andrew Ryan that newcomers and especially fans of the first game will love. Phoebe Lamb is the near antithesis of Andrew Ryan, and just as villainous for it, which is a refreshing change of pace. The ability to kill or spare certain key characters and the fact that such choices actually do have an impact on the story really adds to the replay value here. While the plot lacks the "holy s**t" factor of the original, it is quite well written and acted, and really draws you in, Bioshock fan or not.Multiplayer/GFWL-The game also includes a full fledged multiplayer mode, which is pretty much all of the standard fps game modes you would expect, but from a Bioshock perspective. Throw in a Modern Warfare style leveling and unlock system and a surprisingly well integrated multiplayer backstory and you've got a very solid multiplayer mode. A very nice touch is the inclusion of specific characters with unlock able audio diaries, backstories and customizable appearances in lieu of traditional custom skins and models. They also have high quality voice acting for these avatars. A particularly nice touch is the in game player apartment, which serves as a front for a standard multiplayer menu, and gives us an incredibly atmospheric glimpse of life on the eve of Rapture's collapse. Various pieces of furniture and appliances serve as server browser, audio diary storage, loadout customization, avatar customization, and story introduction. In addition, there are a variety of maps, many of them revamped and cleaned up versions of locations from the first game which add a great deal to this atmospheric multiplayer.However, I have a bone to pick with Bioshock 2, and that is the forced installation of Games for Windows Live, without which you cannot save or load your game. Essentially you are tied to the service, which you are also forced to make an account with. This imposition is reminiscent of Ubisoft's recent DRM debacle and ties PC gamers to what is essentially Xbox Live for PC. I don't want this. Nobody wants this. I already have steam, why should I be forced to install GFWL? A small upset, maybe, but an important one.Ultimately, Bioshock 2 takes the "if it ain't broke don't fix it" approach as a sequel, with some important and welcome exceptions. It doesn't blow my mind as the first one did, but it does do a great deal right, and with a few exceptions it makes very few unwelcome changes. It's a great game and a must buy for fans of the first.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Ah, Bioshock 2. The scrawny, overlooked middle child of the Bioshock franchise. Neither the adrenaline-soaked action of Infinite, nor the dark, atmospheric journey of discovery of the original. Now that I've played it I can see why it was a let down for many. Here is an example of when worlds collide for the worst. The ability to wield the power of the Sith in one hand and the power of the Terminator in the other does not suit the dreary tromp through Rapture's half flooded tunnels. It's an action game in a horror setting, where the action overwhelms any sense of dread, knowing that whatever pops around the corner will find themselves just another red smear on the soggy carpet in the blink of an eye. Writing is far weaker than the original. Sofia Lamb is a little more than Andrew Ryan, except she was found in the clearance aisle of Villains R Us. Like Ryan, she calls out your actions throughout the game, but never succeeds in getting under your skin. Minor villains come and go with no significant buildup nor payoff. The moral choice system is back, too. Just as useless as it was in the first game. Speaking of mechanics, playing as a Big Daddy turns the 'Little Sister Escort' level from the original game into a game mechanic, again with the ability to save or harvest them once their Adam collecting is done. The 'save or harvest' aka 'good or evil' mechanic was already pretty gimmiky in the original game and even more so now. Any player who pays any amount of attention to escorting Little Sisters will be positively swimming in Adam, without a single harvest. All in all, though, Bioshock 2 is still a worthy game, despite feeling more 'DLC' than 'sequel'. It does an admirable job of expanding upon the lore of the original game and fielded some new mechanics that would be refined and put to greater use in Infinite. Had it not need to follow in the footsteps of the original Bioshock it likely would have fared far better than it did. On the note of Bioshock Infinite, the similarities between Bioschocks 2 and Infinite are quite noticeable. Beyond the mechanics there's the father-daughter team, with the daughter as a support character, going up against a deluded tyrant insane with the goal of utopia. There's the insane religious dudes, the frustrated minority, sick of discrimination, and the painting of the protagonist as the harbinger of doom to a close-knit society. Get the feeling that, like Subject Delta, this game is a prototype. At least it's a fun one.

												Just when you thought things couldn't get any more awesome, they do.If you loved the first Bioshock, you'll love the second (this) one.For those who want to start the series here, I would suggest going to the beginning of Rapture and then coming back to this one. While the storyline makes sense if you haven't played the first, it will be a complete picture if you play the first.More dystopia, more splicers, new baddies and a few different game mechanics.This game carries on from Bioshock and does a nice job of it. Starting from about the time Fontane was rising in power and Ryan in dismay, a new "leader" emerges. Dr. Lamb is quite the accomplished Psychiatrist. Her daughter, Eleanor is to be "the one" uniting force in this "utopia".You can kind of see where this is going, of course. Ryan had similar visions, albeit without a child as the visionary.You play a Big Daddy. Yes, those "disgusting and ugly brutes" as Tenenbaum would say.You are the hero but without spoiling too much more, it gets interesting. 2K did a great job in the latter stages of the story telling process and having Eleanor as a guide worked well.If you played the first one, you will notice some game mechanic changes.Keybinds may be wonky to start with but you will explode a rocket at your feet prematurely and accidentally. Well, at least I did.I found the keybinds didn't translate well from the first to the second game so, a little time mapping your keybinds from the first may fix all of that.The research is still there and is a little easier to manage. No longer do you have to switch your weapon from the camera, but now its a video. The more interesting it is, the more research points. There are 4 research stages. As soon as you get the camera, roll that video on everything you see. It helps later on.Hacking is no longer out of the live game environs so, take cover while hacking.Apart from that, have fun slaying the baddies and stay alive out there.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Did you like Bioshock? Then you'll like Bioshock 2! They're really rather similar. The biggest difference is that since you are playing as one of the first Big Daddies, instead of your options being "rescue" or "harvest" little sisters, your options are now "adopt" or "harvest", with adoption requiring you to either drop off the little sister at a port hole for a small amount of ADAM or you set them down near a corpse and defend them from splicers while they gather ADAM for you. I'm a nice guy with a thirst for ADAM so I saved all the little sisters and gathered all the ADAM that I could, so I spent a lot of time fighting off splicers.I played on medium difficulty, and maybe I'm spoiled from recently replaying Bioshock on easy, but Bioshock 2 seems significantly more difficult. You can't carry as many health kits as you could in the first game, and I seem to remember the first one auto-using health kits when your health bottomed out until you ran out of kits. No such luck this time. The tradeoff they made here is that every weapon can be used for a melee attack, rather than having to switch to the melee weapon, which in this game is a massive drill.Now in Bioshock, the melee weapon was traditional Irrational Games wrench. With the electric jolt plasmid (the first plasmid in the game), and the wrench (the first weapon in the game), you could almost beat it without picking up a single other weapon. It was a super effective combo that only got better with support tonics. You have no such luck in Bioshock 2. In fact, as massive drills go, it takes a couple support tonics to make it feel like it's doing some real damage. It's kind of a bummer.The plasmids got a healthy balancing. Winter blast is far more useful than I remember it being in the first game, and even insect swarm is more fun! I didn't really use some of the less hands-on plasmids, like decoy, or scout, or hypnotize. You get the same eight slots for them as in the first game. The tonics are better handled this time too, with no distinction being made between them. You just get a number of slots and you can fill them with whatever tonics you like without regard for their purpose. A lot of them return from the first game, with a handful of new ones suited for the changes in weaponry. Wrench lurker became drill lurker, and what not.There's another for getting all of the weapon upgrades, and towards the end I was beginning to get nervous because I had a lot of upgrades unfulfilled but I found them all regardless. Apparently you won't get every weapon up to full upgrades by the end of the game, so you should be choosy with what weapons you want to use. The game has a nasty habit of giving you a new weapon right after you've come across an upgrade station, and that kind of sucks because you can't un-upgrade a weapon and then use that upgrade station on the new gun.Hacking has changed for the better, unless you've got slow reflexes. Instead of being a game of pipe-dream, it's a simple needle that goes back and forth and you just need to hit the A button when it's over a green section. Sometimes you need to hit a number of green slots to succeed, and if you hit a red slot you set off the security systems, and if you hit a white slot you take damage. It's easier and faster than the first game, and from the start you're given a tool to hack machines from a distance, which replaces the need from the first game to shock them with electric jolt and then run up and hack them.If you've liked Bioshock, this one's a no-brainer. It's more of the first game, but better, with only a little cognitive dissonance from making a sequel to a game that wasn't made to have a sequel. If you didn't like Bioshock, you probably won't like Bioshock 2. It doesn't change enough from the original formula to make it a different game. If you never played the first game, I'd recommend going through it before hopping on Bioshock 2. It's a fantastic game, it's cheap, and Bioshock 2 basically assumes you played the first game and doesn't make an effort to explain the world of Rapture again.

												I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but I have to say that Bioshock 2 is a very lackluster sequel to the marvelous, original Bioshock. It's not that Bioshock 2 sucks. content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Just when you thought things couldn't get any more awesome, they do.If you loved the first Bioshock, you'll love the second (this) one.For those who want to start the series here, I would suggest going to the beginning of Rapture and then coming back to this one. While the storyline makes sense if you haven't played the first, it will be a complete picture if you play the first.More dystopia, more splicers, new baddies and a few different game mechanics.This game carries on from Bioshock and does a nice job of it. Starting from about the time Fontane was rising in power and Ryan in dismay, a new "leader" emerges. Dr. Lamb is quite the accomplished Psychiatrist. Her daughter, Eleanor is to be "the one" uniting force in this "utopia".You can kind of see where this is going, of course. Ryan had similar visions, albeit without a child as the visionary.You play a Big Daddy. Yes, those "disgusting and ugly brutes" as Tenenbaum would say.You are the hero but without spoiling too much more, it gets interesting. 2K did a great job in the latter stages of the story telling process and having Eleanor as a guide worked well.If you played the first one, you will notice some game mechanic changes.Keybinds may be wonky to start with but you will explode a rocket at your feet prematurely and accidentally. Well, at least I did.I found the keybinds didn't translate well from the first to the second game so, a little time mapping your keybinds from the first may fix all of that.The research is still there and is a little easier to manage. No longer do you have to switch your weapon from the camera, but now its a video. The more interesting it is, the more research points. There are 4 research stages. As soon as you get the camera, roll that video on everything you see. It helps later on.Hacking is no longer out of the live game environs so, take cover while hacking.Apart from that, have fun slaying the baddies and stay alive out there.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												So after a five day binge play of the BioShock franchise, here are my thoughts about the second installment. And though I'm going to recommend this title, I want to caveat the fact that it is by far, the worst in the franchise. It's well worth picking up on sale due to the fact that its story line reflects on the other two titles, but not worth it's asking price. Lets get into why....I was warned by a friend that this game was sub par to the original BioShock, but at first blush I was confused as to why. It looked like a vast improvement, with brushed up graphics, new weapons, new enemies, and the ability to play as a Big Daddy. All things that should have made this a block buster game, but are handled so poorly that in the end it actually leaves you very disappointed. Where to start..... The brushed up graphics at first seem to be a big improvement over the original. They fix one of my gripes about the first game with plenty of new Splicers, each with different voices and outfits, they even added new types of Big Daddy. The problem with this is that you eventually notice that what they've done is remove the glassy, 40s stylized look from the first game, and made everyone look more "realistic". This is a huge disappointment, as it damages the mood the first game set and the surreal look, setting Rapture as far away from ordinary as a city at the bottom of the sea should be. And though they did an alright job making the Splicer's look deformed, it's not the same feeling from the first game where things were bulbous and misshaped or looked out of a 40s pulp comic. The Big Daddy suffers from this problem too as they even out its proportions and turn the Little Sisters into just normal girls with headlamps for eyes.Weapons are improved from the first game, with things like a rivet gun, .50 Cal, drill, things a Bid Daddy would carry. However, these guns seem to pack less than the punch you would expect. Splicers are brutal and manage to eat tons of rounds with only hits to the head seeming to do anything. Rather than hacking like the first game, they give you a wrist mounted tool, that fires remote "tubes" that allow you to hack from a distance. This sounds amazing till you discover they nerfed the hacking  from the tube puzzle, to a Pre-Skool metronome color match game. This does nothing to solve my gripe from the first game, where hacking stops being a challenge and becomes a chore that you dread. And to remove ANY challenge from this process is worst of all, patronizing the player and making it more busywork. Ammo is dropped in a frustratingly random way, always seeming to give you rounds for every gun but the one you need, and the first half of the game is so stingy with drops that you will run into the red if not out of almost every round by the time they toss you up against your first boss. Money is also unbalanced, leaving you dry when you most need it, and like BioShock, the limited wallet space is so annoying that it makes you want to punch a kitten in the neck. Also, the game seems to throw a lot of "junk" at you in boxes and dead splicers, that seem to do nothing! In the first game, drinks, smoking, and eating would give you bonus and detraction in stats depending. But in this game, you get swamped with odd food items, tons of drinks, and random objects that flash by you so quickly that you really have no idea what they do or what they're for. You find yourself slamming the "loot all" button and pray that it's doing something beneficial.Next, is the fact that you're playing as an original design Big Daddy, or Delta series. Naturally, this unique and should be an enjoyable adventure, but sadly it isn't. And why? Because for some reason I can't seem to figure out, you are as weak as wet toilet paper. Yes, the massive Big Daddy from BioShock, that can kill you in one shoulder charge, is reduced to something a Splicer can kill with some errant gun fire. And don't give me the excuse that it's because he's and older model, as the game shows in the open that he can crush Splicers with hardly a thought, but once the game starts, all that power is gone. In fact, it feels like you have LESS health than the protagonist from the first game! This is utterly insane. As a Big Daddy, I should be able to swat Splicers like flies, and of course, the other Big Daddy have no problems doing this, yet even though Delta uses Plasmids as well as eight unique weapons, he's still weaker than just about everything. And this really blows, because they could have pulled a huge contrast to the survival aspect from the first game, by utilizing the massive size and armor of the Big Daddy to wade through huge amounts of smaller enemies and larger, more brutal "boss" situations. That's not to say it's all bad, as you can "adopt" Little Sister's from fallen Big Daddy and protect them as they collect ADAM from bodies littered around Rapture. This is rather enjoyable, and creepy as the Little Sister's vocalizations are just bizarre. Another glaring problem with this game is the plot.... The story line to this game, in a word, stinks.... except in winter, when it stinks on ice... It makes little sense, and doesn't do a damn thing to try and sell it to you. The concept is beyond weak, where a character magically shows up to take over after Ryan and Fontaine are dead, and SUPRISE, is an integral part of Rapture though no one deemed her important enough to mention in the first game. And believe me, this woman is so utterly annoying that you'll want to drip poison into your own ear, rather than have to listen to a single word Sofia Lamb has to say. If the first game was trying to covertly extol the Communist agenda (which it didn't), Lamb picks no bones about being a tree hugging, collectivist, self serving, commie pinko ♥♥♥♥♥. This woman is the thing that never shuts up, and she verbally assaults you non stop through the ENTIRE GAME. And truly this is a major problem, because again, all the updates in the graphics department can't save a game with faulty plot. Another huge problem is, after making Delta out to be some long lost dare devil that stumbled onto Rapture they simply drop any explanation of his back story, and even worse, kills him at the end for NO APPARENT REASON! Can you say poor plot device?! Somehow I feel if they hadn't wasted time building a crappy PVP Multi-player mode where adolescent boys can cross♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and brag about how many kills they have, we would have had a more rich single player story. With all that said, there are some very good points about this game that in a way save it. Again, despite the realistic graphics, Bioshock 2 still manages to build a fantastic mood, with some of the visuals giving me chills. There is a large glass window that overlooks the ruins of Rapture that simply made my blood cold, as well as a fantastic scene of a "Rosie" Big Daddy doing something other escorting a Little Sister. There was also a great section where you got to see out of a Little Sister's eyes, where Rapture appears to still be a heavenly place filled with satin drapes, pillows, and rose petals. Sadly, this is mismanaged as well, seeing as the scene is short and serves no more purpose than to be a gimmick to extend the ending. They also do a great job on making you feel Delta's weight, as the floors creek, jumping is limited, and movement slow and methodical. Plasmids are improved and bugs fixed, but again it seems you use the stun ability of the Electric Plasmid more than any other. Voice acting is again is phenomenal despite Lamb, though the mapping suffered because the game is formatted for console rather than PC. To summarize, the game has many faults and at times feels unworthy of being the successor to the original, but still manages to be a good play at the right price. However, if 2K ever decides to pull a mulligan, this game deserves it far more than the original.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												A much better game than the first one, despite being less exploration-based.  Also has many fewer issues with WIndows 7.+ Graphics look pretty much the same as the original.  The humans look a lot better, though.+ Much better gunplay.  Same amount of weapons, but this time, you can dual-wield them with plasmids.  The melee weapon is a drill, and it's actually useful to the point where you could play the entire game dashing and smashing ♥♥♥♥ing everything.  The pistol is now a more powerful rivet gun, the tommygun is now a gatling gun, the single-barrel shotgun is now a supershotgun, etc. Switching between plasmids is a bit of a chore.+ Better, faster hacking mechanics that didn't feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥- Levels aren't as expansive as the original.  They're more linear, which I didn't mind, but it might be a deal-breaker for some.- There are still a few issues with the port, especially in Fontaine Futuristics where I had the game crash many times.  This time, thankfully, your keybinds don't get wiped.- The FOV thing still happens.  Not that terrible since you can use a keybind to set your FOV, but it still happens when you zoom in with the speargun.- Game's easier than the original, partly due to the better guns. Again, it's a console shooter.- No final boss this time, just a final wave of enemies.  I wouldn't mind having Big Daddy Sinclair be the final boss, with more attacks and more health.If you liked the first Bioshock, get this one too.

content:

												I had plenty of time to enjoy the Bioshock and Bioshock 2 series in the past week. I did not skip through the content like it was there for no reason, I've listened to audio logs, opened every chest in game and tried to kill everything that needed killing. I had a blast with Bioshock 1. Smooth experience, no crashes and an overall satisfaction. The end of Bioshock was kinda if-y but hey it was a really good game. Now what can I say about Bioshock 2? Well it was a great game, to be honest I liked the mechanics more than the first part and the story was so intense and beautiful that I got sucked into it and finished the game in 2 days. I will strongly suggest if you haven't played bioshock series to play do so.Now the problems with Bioshock 2.... O My F%#@*! GOD ! ! !First of all I had to spend quite some time figuring out a way to start the game since it was not loading at all and after a two days of brainstorming and forums-searching I found nothing. Then I've decided to delete it and re-install + the already unavailable Games for Windows Live and somehow, somewhat it started.The first 15 minutes of the game were awesome and suddenly CRASH ... like what ?!? Ok no problem I re-started the game and ... nope you've guessed it no auto save every 5 minutes or so, had to start from the beggining. content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I can't actually recommend Bioshock 2 by itself. It's a superb Unreal shooter wrapped in mediocre level design and story. The gunplay is worthy of a sequel to Bioshock, but the story itself fails in one key point: making you care about the characters that occupy the world. Bioshock 1 had great pacing for introducing characters that seemed reasonable and slowly descended into the realm of madness as the game progressed - 2 just throws you into the madhouse and asks that you kindly shoot it up. There are tons of brilliant and unique ideas in Bioshock 2, but they're missing that master touch - it's like a poor imitiation without really understanding the reasoning behind the design decisions of the first game. I have no doubt that with another 8 months and a rewrite the game could've been stellar. If you really like the shooting, then by all means play the main campaign, but that's about all you're going to get from it.The multiplayer is dead nowadays, but it was one of the better Unreal experiences online when it launched since it relied on the excellent gunplay and plasmid mechanics of the campaign.The reason I am recommending this game (on sale) is because of the DLC. Minerva's Den is an excellent piece of design, in both level and story. It's a phenomenal experience and is convincingly alive in the world of Bioshock. Buy the game and DLC (again on sale) and play Minerva's Den. The pacing, writing, dialogue, and thought that went into it is worth of some real Bioshock material. Game: 5/10, DLC: 10/10

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												After playing the first two games in the BioShock series and starting the third, I can honestly say I like 2 more. Gameplay and Customization: BioShock 2 managed to fix the clunkiness of its predecessor when it comes to shooting. It allows iron sights, which is awesome, and quick plasmid usage. The way this works it you have a weapon on your main hand and plasmid on your off hand at the same time. The variety of plasmids is also cool. The customization of BioShock games never cease to amaze me. Whether you want to be big badass Delta with a drill and offensive plasmids, or take a more subtle approach with the spear gun and stealthy plasmids, Bioshock 2 can provide such an experience. Hacking and Research: This game decided to simplify hacking. Instead of having to play a puzzle minigame like in BioShock, you now need to land the hack needle on green or blue zones, green successfuly completeing hack while blue doing the same plus giving a free item. The Research system was overhauled. Instead of taking pictures of the target to gain research, now you have to video tape them. To get the best possible research, one must kill the target using a mixture of weapons, plasmids, npcs or security bots. Story and Atmosphere:	 I don't understand why people don't like the story of BioShock 2. Though it doesnt follow Jacks life, which was clearly ended at the end of BioShock, its still pretty interesting.  The adventure of Delta and Sinclair on their way to save Eleanor was a great idea. They made sure to make you sad when you had to put down Sinclair. Also the endings are either sad of bad, there is no real happy one.  BioShock 2 does a great job in keeping the experience atmospheric, just like in the first game. Overall:	 This game is better than the first one. If you like any of the above features, its a must have. 10/10 would take fall damage to see Delta make a mini earthquake.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												While I do recommend this game, do not think that there are not some things that are less than acceptable =Story- The story is a bit more dumbed down then the first one. The gist of it is you’re a prototype Big Daddy who got resurrected and you need to find your little sister (now grown up). On your journey, you go through misadventure to misadventure. Overall, not the strongest out of the Bioshock seriesGameplay- Gameplay is more polished and improved from the first game. While there are very few new plasmids, the old ones are improved and have more development than the first game (For example, Electro Bolt at Level 3 can shoot a stream of electricity and chain lightning) Gunplay is also very fun, but some weapons are better left untouched at a Power to the People station than others. Overall, solid and entertainingGraphics- The models are a step up from the first game, now more polished and scary looking. Environments are similar to the first game, but with improved textures and a more abandoned feel. In sum, an upgrade from the first game.Control- The controls were fine. You can now duel wield a plasmid and a weapon. Switching weapons and plasmids in a fight could become tricky, but isn't a major fault that affects the game.Difficulty- Identical to the first game, with the added challenge of being limited to 5 medkits and 5 EVE hypos. Most of the time it’s a fair incline, but be prepared to gluttonously consume medkit after medkit during some fights.Polishes- Hacking is improved (Replacing long boring tube puzzles with quick button pressing) Plasmids are fun to use and they defiantly spice up the gameplay. Research is also more innovative, making the player contribute. Low Points- Games for Windows Live (GFWL) sucks. There, I said it. I recommend finding a way to disable it and adding -dx9 to launch options (Oh and stay away from multiplayer if you don't want a sour taste to be left in your mouth). Also, you can't go back to previous areas, so better scavenge the area well. Final Verdict: 7.5/10Bioshock 2 improves upon the first game (gameplay wise), making it more enjoyable to play. However, the games basic plot and lack of social/political commentary may leave some fans disappointed. If you want a game that improves upon the first gameplay wise, but lacks any real voice, I recommend this. Otherwise, it's best to save up $10.00 more to buy Infinite

The game (and Bio 1) already looks pretty good in my opinion.Gameplay: The first few hours are very familiar and I can fully understand people bailing here thinking it's inferior to the first game. However, stick with it and you'll be rewarded in spades. The last three quarters of the game are just excellent. The ending I was given (and there are several) just killed me emotionally. I should probably state that I'm a father!Position in the series: I didn't really rate Infinite very highly. As polished as it looks, it's a hollow shell for me. Bioshock 1 will always be famous for *that* bit, but the ending was fluffed (subjective, obviously). I loved Bioshock 2 and can't wait to play it again soon, it's easily my favourite. The quality of Minerva's Den is the icing on the cake.Oh, and Big Sisters are freaky as hell!

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												This entry in the BioShock series is, to me, a polarizing experience.Standing on its own, this game is incredible. The art design is absolutely mesmerizing, complemented with a sensual soundtrack and astounding voice work. The gameplay is quite intuitive as well; guns feel distinct and your entire arsenal is an equillibrium of diverse offense. Plasmids feel unique and the inclusion of traps allows for a meticulous, strategic approach when protecting Little Sisters' and their harvesting. BioShock 2 succeeds in these aspects, though it falters in others.Comparing this game with BioShock 1, however, proves much dissonance. While BioShock 1 provided enough backstory to support necessary explanation for things in the universe, BioShock 2 unloaded an excess- it feels forced, uninspired, and ultimately like fan fiction. The new information given in BioShock 2 doesn't mesh very well with what BioShock 1 established- the tone of the subject matter feels radically different between the two. The story of this game feels as though it lacks true progression of any sort, and ultimately hinders in pacing and character development. To make this game feel more as if it didn't belong in the main canon, it was entirely neglected in both episodes of Burial at Sea for BioShock Infinite- no mention of any characters, foreshadowing of any sort, and even entirely negates some of things established in BioShock 2.BioShock 2 is a love/hate game- on its own, it stands quite fine. When compared to BioShock 1, it feels entirely unnecesary and unfitting.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Just when you thought things couldn't get any more awesome, they do.If you loved the first Bioshock, you'll love the second (this) one.For those who want to start the series here, I would suggest going to the beginning of Rapture and then coming back to this one. While the storyline makes sense if you haven't played the first, it will be a complete picture if you play the first.More dystopia, more splicers, new baddies and a few different game mechanics.This game carries on from Bioshock and does a nice job of it. Starting from about the time Fontane was rising in power and Ryan in dismay, a new "leader" emerges. Dr. Lamb is quite the accomplished Psychiatrist. Her daughter, Eleanor is to be "the one" uniting force in this "utopia".You can kind of see where this is going, of course. Ryan had similar visions, albeit without a child as the visionary.You play a Big Daddy. Yes, those "disgusting and ugly brutes" as Tenenbaum would say.You are the hero but without spoiling too much more, it gets interesting. 2K did a great job in the latter stages of the story telling process and having Eleanor as a guide worked well.If you played the first one, you will notice some game mechanic changes.Keybinds may be wonky to start with but you will explode a rocket at your feet prematurely and accidentally. Well, at least I did.I found the keybinds didn't translate well from the first to the second game so, a little time mapping your keybinds from the first may fix all of that.The research is still there and is a little easier to manage. No longer do you have to switch your weapon from the camera, but now its a video. The more interesting it is, the more research points. There are 4 research stages. As soon as you get the camera, roll that video on everything you see. It helps later on.Hacking is no longer out of the live game environs so, take cover while hacking.Apart from that, have fun slaying the baddies and stay alive out there.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2013
												Bioshock 2 is a sequel to the original game and was developed by 2K Marin. The game, taking place roughly seven years after Bioshock, follows the story of Subject Delta, an early prototype Big Daddy, as he tries to reunites himself with his original Little Sister while trying to survive the danger of a derelict Rapture, now under the command of a psychiatrist, Sophia Lamb, with total opposite philosophical views from Andrew Ryan.As far as gameplay goes, Bioshock 2 doesn't introduce anything exactly breathtaking over the first game's formula, only tweaking some elements and adding some novelities along the line. The biggest difference between the first and the second game is that now you can fire plasmids and weapons at the same time, hack security machines and other mechanism remotely thanks to a dedicated tool, several enemies from the original game are now more dangerous one way or the other and you'll have to face far more kinds of elite enemies (and not all of them are Big Daddies). As far as general difficulty goes Bioshock 2 manages to be a mixed bag: while the opposition you will encounter is far more deadly than the one in the first game, you are given plenty of new plasmids, tonics and weapons to compensate, and, much like the other games in the series, Bioshock 2 actually becomes easier as you progress into it.The story of Bioshock 2 was recived in a variety of ways. The main plot is, at its core, a self-insert fic which tries to expand the characters and the story of the first game while introducing some new elements that however do tend to make little sense at times (the biggest problem here being that we are introduced to new characters and events that were supposedly of major importance in Rapture's history, and therefore should had been mentioned in the original Bioshock too). There is also some consent that the plot of the original game didn't need an expansion whatsoever. Still, Bioshock 2 manages to tell a fairly good story on its own thanks to a cast of (mostly) interesting and emotional characters. The game also features a rudimentary moral system: depending of few decisions you are called to make regarding the Little Sisters and some major NPCs, you can get a different ending.Bioshock 2 also features a multiplayer mode, dubbed "The Fall of Rapture". However, as I'm writing this review, this mode has been pretty much abbandoned and it's downright impossible to meet other players, let alone start any match. It's worth mentioning that Bioshock 2 multiplayer wasn't exactly that well recived though.As it stands, Bioshock 2 feels pretty much like an expansion pack for the original Bioshock instead of a deep, epic and completely overhauled sequel. If you can get over this fact, however, you will find that the game is genuinely enjoyable on many levels

content:
Posted: October 3, 2013
												Bioshock 2 is a sequel to the original game and was developed by 2K Marin. The game, taking place roughly seven years after Bioshock, follows the story of Subject Delta, an early prototype Big Daddy, as he tries to reunites himself with his original Little Sister while trying to survive the danger of a derelict Rapture, now under the command of a psychiatrist, Sophia Lamb, with total opposite philosophical views from Andrew Ryan.As far as gameplay goes, Bioshock 2 doesn't introduce anything exactly breathtaking over the first game's formula, only tweaking some elements and adding some novelities along the line. The biggest difference between the first and the second game is that now you can fire plasmids and weapons at the same time, hack security machines and other mechanism remotely thanks to a dedicated tool, several enemies from the original game are now more dangerous one way or the other and you'll have to face far more kinds of elite enemies (and not all of them are Big Daddies). As far as general difficulty goes Bioshock 2 manages to be a mixed bag: while the opposition you will encounter is far more deadly than the one in the first game, you are given plenty of new plasmids, tonics and weapons to compensate, and, much like the other games in the series, Bioshock 2 actually becomes easier as you progress into it.The story of Bioshock 2 was recived in a variety of ways. The main plot is, at its core, a self-insert fic which tries to expand the characters and the story of the first game while introducing some new elements that however do tend to make little sense at times (the biggest problem here being that we are introduced to new characters and events that were supposedly of major importance in Rapture's history, and therefore should had been mentioned in the original Bioshock too). There is also some consent that the plot of the original game didn't need an expansion whatsoever. Still, Bioshock 2 manages to tell a fairly good story on its own thanks to a cast of (mostly) interesting and emotional characters. The game also features a rudimentary moral system: depending of few decisions you are called to make regarding the Little Sisters and some major NPCs, you can get a different ending.Bioshock 2 also features a multiplayer mode, dubbed "The Fall of Rapture". However, as I'm writing this review, this mode has been pretty much abbandoned and it's downright impossible to meet other players, let alone start any match. It's worth mentioning that Bioshock 2 multiplayer wasn't exactly that well recived though.As it stands, Bioshock 2 feels pretty much like an expansion pack for the original Bioshock instead of a deep, epic and completely overhauled sequel. If you can get over this fact, however, you will find that the game is genuinely enjoyable on many levels

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Bioshock 2 provides an interesting second look at the world of Rapture, expanding on the story set by the first game. The gameplay is arguably improved a bit from the first game, with a broader weapon set and extra polish, as well as some tweaked plasmids (Security Command is a fun one- lets you summon flying security bots wherever you are). However, the storyline feels a bit grindy and aimless, with the main character's goals feeling relatively unmotivated compared to those in the first game Yeah, he's dying, but for some reason it just doesn't feel compelling. You never actually meet two of the big characters in the game- Sinclair and Sofia Lamb- in any major role physically, so they just feel like voices in your head for most of the game. Also, this game is as glitchy as the first, if not more, and will probably crash you out to the desktop more than a couple times. Quicksave will be your best friend. Reservations aside, I highly recommend this game, because the slight complaints I have are well worth sticking through for the experience of the game as a whole.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I can't actually recommend Bioshock 2 by itself. It's a superb Unreal shooter wrapped in mediocre level design and story. The gunplay is worthy of a sequel to Bioshock, but the story itself fails in one key point: making you care about the characters that occupy the world. Bioshock 1 had great pacing for introducing characters that seemed reasonable and slowly descended into the realm of madness as the game progressed - 2 just throws you into the madhouse and asks that you kindly shoot it up. There are tons of brilliant and unique ideas in Bioshock 2, but they're missing that master touch - it's like a poor imitiation without really understanding the reasoning behind the design decisions of the first game. I have no doubt that with another 8 months and a rewrite the game could've been stellar. If you really like the shooting, then by all means play the main campaign, but that's about all you're going to get from it.The multiplayer is dead nowadays, but it was one of the better Unreal experiences online when it launched since it relied on the excellent gunplay and plasmid mechanics of the campaign.The reason I am recommending this game (on sale) is because of the DLC. Minerva's Den is an excellent piece of design, in both level and story. It's a phenomenal experience and is convincingly alive in the world of Bioshock. Buy the game and DLC (again on sale) and play Minerva's Den. The pacing, writing, dialogue, and thought that went into it is worth of some real Bioshock material. Game: 5/10, DLC: 10/10
