content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												This game has been out for years, and has been notoriously buggy the whole time it's been on the market.  2k Games has the werewithal to remove GFWL in order to sell this pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥on Steam, but can't be bothered to fix long-standing, game-stopping bugs?  Unbelievable.It's hard not to recommend this game, because so much of it is just really, really good.  At times, better than the original Bioshock.  The graphics are gorgeous, the environments even more realistic, with an original story that maintains and expands on the mythology of the Bioshock universe.  The problem with Bioshock 2 is that it is crash-prone.  If you manage to not have frequent crashes, then chances are you are either extrememly lucky, or you found one of the so-called fixes that help.  It seems like there is a different fix for every level, because every single time I was heading into, or was playing in, a new area it would crash and I'd have to hunt down a so-called "fix".  Let's see, at various times I've forced it to run in directx9 mode, set it to use directx10, deleted saves from the savegame folder, turned down the graphics to their lowest possible setting, turned off the reverb, edited the ini file, verified the game files, killed the ATI Catalyst Control program, I have no antivirus running, nor any bakground programs other than Steam, I've set it to run in compatibility mode, and I've set it to Run as Administrator.  Even when you do manage that, a second even uglier issue may arise:  dropping to the menu system to save your progress only to find the save button isn't there.  Not only is it not there, but hitting escape to go back to the game asks you if you want to quit to windows.  You can select continue or load game, but it will erase your progress anyway.  This has happened to me so many times and I'm only half way through the game.  And whatever you do, don't save your game on exit - it's known to corrupt your saves.  I was able to use the various "fixes" found around the web to get around one crash or another throughout playing this game, but I've come to a point in the game where nothing I do matters.  It crashes like clockwork, on cue, in the loading transition between Dionysus Park and Fontaine Futuristics.  Ya know what?  I'm done.  I really don't have the time and fortitude to put up with this game any longer.  And I will certainly be sure not purchase any products from 2K Games in the future.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												First, let me say the following in all fairness: 2K tried. No matter what the final outcome, for better or for worse, they tried to make a good game. And in many ways, they did good work on this title. The combat actually feels better than in the original Bioshock, being more fluent and giving you more options. Hacking has been significantly improved as you no longer have to play a mini game endlessly to get it to work. Saying that a quick time event actually improved this issue sounds odd, but I assure you, it is true.The game also looks stunning. Rapture is simply gorgeous in Bioshock 2. A clear step above from its predecessor in that aspect as well. So visually and mechanically speaking, the game is just fine. If those are the things that are important to you in Bioshock game, I have nothing negative to report to you about Bioshock 2. Unfortunately, the most important parts of any Bioshock game for me, personally, are the characters and the story. And that regard, Bioshock 2 falls flat on its big dumb face.First off, let's consider the character you play. Supposedly, you are prototype Big Daddy who was forgotten in the bowels of Rapture until you are reactivated and asked to help out. So right off the bat, Bioshock 2 feels like a lazy fan game. You aren't really a character the way you were in the other two games. You are merely a prop that lumbers from place to place while being asked "Isn't it so cool that you get to be a Big Daddy" in the most pandering way possible.Playing as Jack in Bioshock or Booker DeWitt in Bioshock Infinite just felt right. It felt like you were playing a key figure and participant in the ongoing narrative. Playing a supposed Big Daddy in Bioshock 2 feels downright silly. For one thing - as the great Ben "Yahtzee" Croshaw rightly pointed out - you aren't really a Big Daddy.As a "Prototype", you can now move at normal speed, use weapons and even Plasmids. So basically, you are a Big Daddy in look only. In function, you may as well be anyone. Moreover, being asked to believe you are a prototype Big Daddy raises the question of why the Big Daddy designers stripped the ability to move normally, use weapons and use Plasmids out of the later models, replaced with simply being able to lumber around at a slow pace and punch things with your drill. The answer is, they wouldn't do that. It's all the worst kind of shoehorning in for the sake of player convenience.The whole concept of playing a prototype Big Daddy just feels wrong. Rather than feeling like a key figure in the narrative, you feel more like a "Thing" that the designers let you play because Big Daddy + Popular = Delta. Moreover - as Yahtzee also noted - while the designers forced you to lumber around as a supposed Big Daddy, they kept all the game mechanics from the first Bioshock the same. So just as you could as Jack in Bioshock, you can still find candy bars and bags of chips to eat and regain health. But whereas Jack had an actual mouth that wasn't obscured by anything, as a Big Daddy I guess you're cramming it all through your face plate? o_O Never has a concept felt so tacked on as the notion of playing a Big Daddy. It adds nothing to the narrative and only serves to make you feel a bit stupid as the details noted above begin to erode the immersion.Another big problem with the narrative has to do with the people you encounter in Rapture this time around. The characters you met in Bioshock were vivid, three dimensional people who were as unforgettable as Rapture itself. Who could forget Doctor Steinman's cries of frustration as he couldn't seem to get his latest surgery victim to come out just right while noting the backdrop of all his previous victims? Who could forget Sander Cohen's blatant disregard for poor, poor Fitzpatrcik as he blew him up for not playing his piano solo in tune?The problem with Bioshock 2' is that at the end of the first Bioshock, every interesting character in Rapture was either dead or gone (depending on how you play. If you have enough mercy and forgiveness in your heart, you can let the sick ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sander Cohen live). So with the exception of Tenenbaum - who serves as mere cameo in this one - 2K was forced to come up with their own characters from scratch. The result is the most unforgettable bunch I've ever met in a video game. There is a significant lack of meaning that anyone in Rapture has in this game. The characters in Bioshock all represented something that tied in to the narrative of Objectivism and its ideals. Doctor Steinman represented the medical practice unbound by the limitations of the Hippocratic oath. Cohen represented art as unrestrained by regulation, censorship or basic human decency.But - for example - In Bioshock 2, you meet Simon Wales... who designed Rapture. ... ... I'm not sure what he's supposed to represent aside from "The guy who designed Rapture". And that's really the crux of my problem with the narrative in Bioshock 2. Bioshock and Bioshock Infinite were all about concepts that were bigger than the games themselves. Bioshock 2 is just a game about Bioshock. And that holds no interest for me.But now we come to perhaps my biggest problem with the whole thing: Sophia Lamb. This lazy pile of main villain garbage is one of the worst Ret-Cons I've seen crammed into any video game or indeed in any form of entertainment period. This character just doesn't fit in the world of Rapture. And that's even just when the game gets started. To say nothing about the game trying to make us accept that she had been there the whole time in Bioshock, yet was never mentioned once.Everyone we encountered in Bioshock had a reason to be there. They were all attracted to Rapture in some way because Ryan's ideals and ideas freed them from basic sociological constraints, and they all ran amok as a result. There is no reason in the world why a character like Sophia Lamb would even want to go to a place like Rapture. There was nothing for her down there. And to suggest that she wanted to try and influence Rapture's ideals to her way of thinking and change that world from within is simply laughable, because it would have been such an impossible uphill battle that she - in reality - wouldn't even have bothered. And it adds tragic insult to injury when we are asked to believe that Andrew Ryan actually challenged Sophia Lamb to a public debate wherein both argued their philosophies back and forth to one another. No. I'm sorry. Just - No. Andrew Ryan would never - EVER give legitimacy and/or equal time to someone with Lamb's ideals! Let alone publicly! Someone who was that much an affront to everything Rapture and Ryan stood for would simply have been dealt with. Not debated. There's also an inherent laziness to the very concept of Sophia lamb as the villain. It's as if she was created in a 2K board meeting where someone said "What was Andrew Ryan again? Objectivist and quasi-libertarian? Well just make this villain whatever that isn't. Cult leader and pseudo-communist? Sure, there we go, whatever". And then slapped all those traits onto her like a half written bumper sticker. We saw something similar to those opposing traits in in Bioshock Infinite, but Comstock, Columbia and its ideals were all a contrast to Rapture, Andrew Ryan and Objectivism. Sophia Lamb is just tthe opposite of what Andrew Ryan was. So whereas these similar ideas were ambitious in Infinite, they're simply lazy in Bioshock 2.It all comes across as the laziest kind of fan fiction. And that's exactly what Bioshock 2 feels like: A fan game. If you play this game for mere enjoyment, than it's perfectly serviceable and certainly fun. At least at times. But the narrative is so broken and stupid that it just sin't worth playing for me, or even considering it a legitimate entry into the Bioshock world at all. It's the Star Trek V of Bioshock games. Personally, I don't even count it.

												If you played Bioshock 1, you know what to expect. It is a GREAT sequel. The story in BS2 though, was better, I feel, than in part 1. It's 3 rivets and some splicers. By the end of the game, you are so turned off by the combat you're just running through halls to get to the end. It was so annoying it ruined the game for me.The combat mechanics are poor. This game rewards players who choose to die over and over(because nothing bad happens, youre brought back life. done.) instead of players who shoot with speed and accuracy and forethought. The enemies are awfully skewed, sometimes fighting splicers that are tougher than big daddies, or having some splicers refuse to die. For example when you first get the spear gun you one shot kill the splicers you first shoot. After commiting the same slaughter to one splicer, i turn to another in his group who takes two to the head, and two to the chest and almost another clip of 50 mil. Not a boss, because the bosses are actually wimps in this game compared to the hordes of common zombie types you face, just one splicer who felt tough i guess. taking at least a clip to kill an enemy up close and personal fully upgraded, this is the only game i've seen that makes a 50 cal machine gun look like ♥♥♥♥♥. 												-Pathetic console port-Total lack of technical integrity; prone to lag and crashing-Half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ overly simplistic story that tries desperately to expand and replicate the depth, complexity, and philosophical waxing of the first game and fails miserably-Contradicts the first game's story at every other turn-Mediocre level design which does nothing to compensate for the familiarity you'll undoubtedly feel with Rapture if you've played the first game, thus completely cancelling out any possible horror factor♥♥♥♥♥♥poor balance of stealth and action; the game places way too much emphasis on action over stealth; gameplay is somehow extremely tedious and boring despite this-Levels are way too big; the original game saw you exploring as you furthered the story, this one sees you exploring INSTEAD of furthering the story-Clunky UI due to dual-wielding of plasmids and weapons putting way too much object in the foreground (see Bioshock Infinite for a guide on how to properly set up dual-wielding in an FPS)-Reinvents the wheel by introducing a slew of new plasmids, weapons, upgrades, and gene tonics which supposedly update and refine the gameplay, but are ultimately unnecessary and just confuse things-Worst audio ever in a video game; some sounds come through way too quiet while others come through extremely loudIn other words, Bioshock 2 is an unoriginal cash cow- a pathetic attempt at expanding and recreating a sheer masterpiece of our time, in true sequelitis fashion. Everything about it is either boring or frustrating or just plain makes no sense. It is one of the most unnecessary games ever created. It's Bioshock minus the charm, horror, nostalgia, intelligence, and atmosphere that made the first Bioshock such a perfect game. To quote a Metacritic reviewer, "Should be called Bioshock Light. Or Bioshock Megablast." Honestly, it feels closer in spirit to the Call of Duty series than it does to its own prequel.The only redeeming factor it possesses is that Irrational Games, the team behind Bioshock 1 and Bioshock Infinite, had absolutely nothing to do with this garbage, so I don't even have to acknowledge it as canon if I don't want to.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												BioShock 2 is quite a good example of a game that didn't really need to exist. BioShock 1 was a self-contained story and ended nicely with any and all loose ends suitably tied up so what could a sequel to one of the best games of 2007 possibly bring to the table? The answer is quite a lot!BioShock 2 is a First-Person Shooter game with stealth and horror elements and is set in the year 1968, 8 years after the events of BioShock 1. You play as a Big Daddy and, after an incident 10 years ago, have just been reactivated. You are tasked with finding your Little Sister and are caught in the middle of an attempted takeover of the decaying city. Since our last trip through Rapture, things have gotten much worse but you are not just any old lumbering slow Big Daddy though. You are Delta, a Prototype Big Daddy with the ability to use different weapons and Plasmids.Irrational Games did not make BioShock 2. The duty was given to 2K Marin. The result is a pretty damn good game, it just doesn't feel as polished as the original does.Right off the bat, the majority of the environments appear very nicely detailed and it is clear that a lot of work has gone into them. It is best not to look too close however, some inaccessible parts of some levels look quite bad. I have clear memories of one corridor ending in a completely black wall!For the first three hours or so of the game, it's environments are less open than BioShock's levels. It goes through teaching you the basics of play, who the characters are, what your role in the world is and the game eventually opens up a little bit and gives you the freedom to explore.Instead of BioShock 1's combat mechanics where you could only use either a weapon or a plasmids at any one time, In BioShock 2 you have control of both hands; your left hand uses Plasmids and your right hand uses your weapons. This makes combat a lot more fun and feel much more responsive. No more faffing around trying to find the plasmid or weapon you want whilst being defenceless. Now you can try out different combinations with your plasmid powers when they are powerful enough. put a Cyclone Trap down and zap it with Electro Bolt or Incinerate and see what might happen. Get experimenting! And Yes, Cyclone Trap is still as hilarious as it always has been.As for game-play and game progression, there isn't much difference to the first game. If you've played BioShock 1 then you will feel right at home for BioShock 2. The only difference is, being a Big Daddy, you get to interact with the Little Sisters a bit more. In order to get Adam, you'll have to get yourself a Little Sister who is usually being protected by another Big Daddy. Once dispatching of the Big Daddy, you are free to gather Adam for yourself or Harvest the Little Sister.The whole process of gathering Adam for yourself is one of the game's better points. Building up a defence and watching it all go off while your Little Sister does her thing is quite satisfying. But you better be careful... not everyone may appreciate you taking the Adam for yourself...BioShock had an extremely tense atmosphere to it; the levels were dark, the scares were genuinely scary and the music really helped to enhance the tension. In BioShock 2, this scary fun is largely missing and when the game does attempt to unnerve you, I found that it just fell flat. Slightly disappointing. I do believe that the music may have been broken in a few places as, upon reloading a previous save one time, music would start playing where there previously had been nothing playing at all.And, while the story isn't ever going to meet that of the first game, it really does pick up towards the end with some incredibly beautifully created sections and environments to match. I wont spoil anything but it really did impress that they could do what they did with the technology.They did a better job with hacking though. Instead of a 2 minute long pipemania style game, the player can now simply time button presses correctly in a much quicker and simpler hacking minigame.While the key-bindings work fine, they may break when given on-screen prompts. I was given a choice of adopting a Little Sister and, with no updated bindings on-screen to tell me what button did what, had to just kind of press a button and hope that it was the right action I wanted to take. Luckily it was.And now, its time to talk about all that DLC that came along after release. I remember 2K thinking and delaying and rethinking about whether or not to release this DLC on PC at all. Thankfully they did and it should not be missed! Here's a run-down. Protector Trials DLC - This DLC is exactly what its name sounds like it is; Take the process of protecting a little sister from splicers and turns it into its own mini-game!Minerva's Den DLC - Absolutely incredible from start to finish. Take BioShock 2's mechanics, BioShock 1's darker horror-themed and better constructed environments and triple the size of the levels and you have Minerva's Den, a self-contained story with about 12-16 hours worth of entertainment to it. It's almost impossible to say anything about anything inside this DLC without spoiling things but trust me... you need to play this if you have BioShock 2.At the time of writing this review, I have not played the multi-player. I do know that it was made by a separate studio as to give the single player team the time they needed to create the single player without any distractions. It has an interesting side-story to it; It is set prior to the fall of Rapture and you are a plasmid test subject for Sinclair Solutions. A Civil War is breaking out and it's your job to go and smack some of your fellow citizens around a bit. I'll update this review later when I get around to playing it.Overall, BioShock 2 does the combat better than BioShock 1 but the story never really had a hope of matching. It is a game that is definitely worth playing though and the DLC is up there with some of the best Single Player DLC I have ever played. The Shock series of games continues to be of a high standard of quality even if BioShock 2 does falter in a few small places.

This makes combat a lot more fun and feel much more responsive. No more faffing around trying to find the plasmid or weapon you want whilst being defenceless. Now you can try out different combinations with your plasmid powers when they are powerful enough. put a Cyclone Trap down and zap it with Electro Bolt or Incinerate and see what might happen. Get experimenting! And Yes, Cyclone Trap is still as hilarious as it always has been.As for game-play and game progression, there isn't much difference to the first game. If you've played BioShock 1 then you will feel right at home for BioShock 2. The only difference is, being a Big Daddy, you get to interact with the Little Sisters a bit more. In order to get Adam, you'll have to get yourself a Little Sister who is usually being protected by another Big Daddy. Once dispatching of the Big Daddy, you are free to gather Adam for yourself or Harvest the Little Sister.The whole process of gathering Adam for yourself is one of the game's better points. Building up a defence and watching it all go off while your Little Sister does her thing is quite satisfying. But you better be careful... not everyone may appreciate you taking the Adam for yourself...BioShock had an extremely tense atmosphere to it; the levels were dark, the scares were genuinely scary and the music really helped to enhance the tension. In BioShock 2, this scary fun is largely missing and when the game does attempt to unnerve you, I found that it just fell flat. Slightly disappointing. I do believe that the music may have been broken in a few places as, upon reloading a previous save one time, music would start playing where there previously had been nothing playing at all.And, while the story isn't ever going to meet that of the first game, it really does pick up towards the end with some incredibly beautifully created sections and environments to match. I wont spoil anything but it really did impress that they could do what they did with the technology.They did a better job with hacking though. Instead of a 2 minute long pipemania style game, the player can now simply time button presses correctly in a much quicker and simpler hacking minigame.While the key-bindings work fine, they may break when given on-screen prompts. I was given a choice of adopting a Little Sister and, with no updated bindings on-screen to tell me what button did what, had to just kind of press a button and hope that it was the right action I wanted to take. Luckily it was.And now, its time to talk about all that DLC that came along after release. I remember 2K thinking and delaying and rethinking about whether or not to release this DLC on PC at all. Thankfully they did and it should not be missed! Here's a run-down. Protector Trials DLC - This DLC is exactly what its name sounds like it is; Take the process of protecting a little sister from splicers and turns it into its own mini-game!Minerva's Den DLC - Absolutely incredible from start to finish. Take BioShock 2's mechanics, BioShock 1's darker horror-themed and better constructed environments and triple the size of the levels and you have Minerva's Den, a self-contained story with about 12-16 hours worth of entertainment to it. It's almost impossible to say anything about anything inside this DLC without spoiling things but trust me... you need to play this if you have BioShock 2.At the time of writing this review, I have not played the multi-player. I do know that it was made by a separate studio as to give the single player team the time they needed to create the single player without any distractions. It has an interesting side-story to it; It is set prior to the fall of Rapture and you are a plasmid test subject for Sinclair Solutions. A Civil War is breaking out and it's your job to go and smack some of your fellow citizens around a bit. I'll update this review later when I get around to playing it.Overall, BioShock 2 does the combat better than BioShock 1 but the story never really had a hope of matching. It is a game that is definitely worth playing though and the DLC is up there with some of the best Single Player DLC I have ever played. The Shock series of games continues to be of a high standard of quality even if BioShock 2 does falter in a few small places.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												I would give Bioshock 2 a 5/10, as it was worse than the original in every way.Bioshock 2 is a first person shooter with RPG elements, similar to the first game in the series. If you have not played the first game, don't read this review and play the original, as it will be a much more enjoyable experience and set you up for this one in case you wish to play them all. If you have played the original, then know that I thought this game inferior in nearly every way, though not terrible.Bioshock 2 does add some new enemies, as well as plasmids, to the gameplay, giving a new feel to some of the battles. The loot is still found a plenty, the enemies are still tough, and there are some sequences in the game that you will find yourself really enjoying, just like the first game.But some of the other aspects that Bioshock did so well, such as interesting villains, moral choices, a sense of new-ness and intrigue, and excellent story progression, this game misses the mark on. I thought the story was lame and that the characters were uninteresting, leaving the only real strenghts as the new additions during fights.Especially near the end, I found myself becoming bored. I no longer looked forwards to the fights, and I dreaded any plot twists because it meant that the game was going to continue. I simply wanted to finish the game to make sure that I didn't miss anything, instead of the enjoy the experience. This game wound up being more of a chore to get through by the end than one to enjoy. It does bring some new enemies and plasmids to the game which adds some variety, as well as a couple of new perspectives during some of the levels. Despite that, it just winds up being boring, via both gameplay and story, as i found myself not really caring by the end and just being frustrated. If you are dying to see more of Rapture, or are a big fan of the Bioshock series, you may enjoy it, but just be warned that it is inferior to the first and third installments.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												It was inevitable that a financial success like the original Bioshock would get a sequel. I wasn't overwhelmed with the first game of the series; I thought it average at best, despite some occasionally interesting architecture and some neat water effects. The second in the series is more of the same... or perhaps less.Whereas the original Bioshock tried to be an action/RPG, the sequel disposes of most of the role-playing baggage; the game throws you into the action from the start and doesn't let up until the end. There are still some lingering remnants -you still upgrade your weapons and plasmids as choice (and collected resources) allow- but the mission structure has been much simplified. There are no branching quests; Bioshock 2 is a linear corridor shooter to the end and is the better game for it.Better than the original, anyway; it still sometimes lets its style take precedence over story and gameplay (the final "oh my god, the place is about to explode; here are a bunch of hour-long quests you need to complete in the meanwhile" a perfect example of this). But the weapons and powers are more interesting, the architecture is still occasionally wonderful and the water effects are both neat and more plentiful. It may be damning the game with faint praise to say its a superior game to the first but given my low expectations I was pleasantly surprised. Hardly a classic, lacking innovation but competent. That's a step in the right direction, anyway.Feeling like unimaginative leftovers cut from the original, Bioshock 2 lacks the novelty of the first game. Too many of its levels and bosses seemed to have been put in more to pad out the gameplay than to advance the plot, which was shallow enough to begin with. The only vaguely interesting bit was (spoiler?) near the end when you get to see the world through the eyes of the waif-like "Little Sisters", but even then it's too short and too limited in scope to redeem the game. The "Minerva's Den" DLC fared a bit better - at least there was some new artwork and weapons - but the gameplay remained tired and uninteresting. And I quit the "Protector Trials" - which extend the least- interesting parts of the game (the Defend the Sister battles) to tiresome lengths - mere minutes after starting.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Did you play the original Bioshock?  Then you've played Bioshock 2, and the sound is still borked.This sequel was actually done by a different studio, but apparently not wanting to mess with success they remade the same game.  Vita chambers are back.  The research camera is back.  Plasmids are back.  The choice to "harvest or save" a little sister is back. Fighting big daddies is back as well.  Even some of the new twists, like playing as a big daddy, don't feel that different in actual gameplay.So, it is essentially the same game, but the novelety has worn off.  You are playing in Rapture, a city built as a Utopia but collapsed into a waring society of ugly drug addicts.  Just like you did in Bioshock.  Adam Ryan has been replaced by Sofia Lamb, who replaces Objectivism with extreme collectivisim.  The two barely seem different despite the polar opposing philosophies.  Since this game is so identical to its predecessor, that means all the problems of the first are back.  The combat still feels clunky.  Vita chambers make the game infinitely easy to beat and destroy the need for resource management.  However, the one problem I just can't look past is the broken sound effects.  Maybe this is a PC problem, maybe this is just a problem for people who use headphones.  Regardless, the game fails to do sound effects properly, with ambient noises such as splicer cries drowning out sound effects like explosions or gunfire.  It is really disconcerting.  For a more original game, like say the original Bioshock, I can work through it.  This time around, it is just inexcusable.  Good news, though.  2K recently updated Bioshock 2 to removal the atrocious Windows Live system, and add achievements.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												This game is pretty much worse than the original in every single way, especially storywise. That said, it's enjoyable for a bit, though it gets tedious after awhile. Fortunately there's the handy dandy super broken hypnotize plasmid that lets you speedrun the game when you've decided you have enough!So basically the plot goes something like crazy lady steals all the lolis because she wants to change Rapture from Somalia to Sweden by making some superpowered loligod with no sentience  to rule over everyone else with impartiality. Or something incredibly dumb like that. Sounds eerily familiar... It's clear that the game was trying to portray the antagonist turning Rapture into collectivist dystopia, opposite of Andrew Ryan's philosophy. It might have worked, but they didn't really stick with it after the first two hours or so and the result is some incredibly bland chapters. For most of the game it feels like you're just following the arrow to kill the guy who has the key to open the next place and not pursuing the plot. The preacher and the guy in the gardens ("I LOCKED MYSELF IN THIS ROOM UNTIL YOU SAVE/KILL 3 SISTERS, SO THERE!!!"). Some of the bold and lofty lines are there, but not enough. It all melts together quite quickly.I realize now why Bioshock Infinite had a new setting vs. the other two entries in the franchise: because it sets the theme. It compliments the storytelling. In Bioshock 2 the atmosphere does not compliment the story. It's just there because it's there. Because it was the setting of a universally acclaimed game and the publisher was determined to make more money off of it somehow.The game also offers little positive in the way of new, meaningful changes to gameplay compared to Bioshock 1. Big Daddy fights were reduced to "equip ice drill, run around big daddy in a circle." Plasmids are pretty much the same save for a few useless new ones, and an altered one that is completely game breaking. To get all the Adam you guard the little sisters. 2x per sister. Up to 3 sisters per level. Six times. Extremely cheap way of lengthening the game and you bet it gets tedious. Honestly the core gameplay was never super amazing in Bioshock, but without another draw in the game it really shows. I don't remember feeling like every gun did zero damage in the original.Bottom line is that this game is basically Opposing Force. Or Blue Shift. Or one of the original F.E.A.R. expansions. It's a level pack for the original. It's even got the "play as one of the other guys!" thing going on! In other words, if you really really really really liked the gameplay in the original it's worth playing for that. Otherwise it is not worth your time.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Once you get past the first hour or so of cinematic and sumptuous level design of Bioshock 2 and find yourself facing the same narrow set of bullet-soaking enemies respawning behind you, the weak story, with its tired tropes and lack of logical resolutions, begins to fail to make up for all other shortcomings. Parts of Rapture are gorgeous, especially early on, but by the halfway point you've seen everything on the menu, and the final level is so numbingly linear, giant UI arrow pointing precisely the direction you must go included, that I stopped looking around long before I slogged through the end sequence. Yes, there is magic here. Literally as well as figuratively, with plasmids imbuing your Delta Big Daddy self with the fire, ice, and lightning powers more commonly associated with a sword & sworcery adventure, but also set pieces with Big Sisters appearing outside viewports and mooks dancing to soft jazz. But too little. Ultimately, the role of plasmids is to set mooks up for a killing blow via melee or headshot, and most environments are water-ruined corridors filled with mobs of comically overdressed psychopaths just waiting around for Big Daddy to walk by. The guns, though varied, have mushy control feel and erratic damage output. Even with the headshot tonic, I found myself needing to shoot later-level enemies multiple times with powerful ammunition. By contrast, the drill was almost too powerful; once frozen, any enemy apart from other Big Daddies (except Alphas) and Big Sisters can be killed with a single blow. I found switching between guns frustratingly slow, and my frustrations were increased by the placement of camera and hacking tool on the scroll wheel (at positions 3 and 5, seemingly randomly). Why the camera couldn't be activated by 'c' and the hack tool by 'h' instead of having them in the scroll wheel is beyond me. Optional audiologs scattered throughout the levels provided interesting additions to the main dialogue, but were often overread by the latter as I moved through levels while listening. The characters are all absurd caricatures, either one-dimensional or simply opaque. Why any of them elected to remain alone (in sanity) in Rapture for years after its downfall is a mystery unexplained at any point throughout the game. Overall, I can say I did enjoy parts of Bioshock 2 enough to justify a discounted purchase from the Steam store, but I would never recommend a full-price purchase.

												Bioshock 1 was a fantastic experience with a great a story, fantastic art direction and unique premise. Bioshock 2 is at best a cookie cutter of the original, and at worst, a poor copy that has somehow been bootlegged into it's own game. A inconsistant story is the worst crime here, and while your limitations as a human are explained reasonably in Bioshock 1, your weaknesses as a big daddy, as well as your abilities have no rationale. Why can you use plasmids? How does one "awaken" a Big Daddy? Why am I so damn weak? In the end, the game trys to explain some of these issues, but they feel contrived and thought up on the spot in order justify using some of Bioshock 1's game mechanics. In the end, you don't feel like the badass big daddys you saw in the first game. You feel used and played like Jack. They might as well have started the game with "Would you kindly enjoy our sequel."

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												After completing the piece of art that is the original BioShock, my expectations of the sequel was high - but not too high, since I doubted it would be better than the original. What I got, I didn't like. The story and athmosphere that the original game had, BioShock 2 completely lacked. I understand that it's hard to make a sequel to that kind of game, but playing as a Big Daddy wasn't as fun. And let's not forget to mention the controls - they were awful! Almost no button corresponds to the original game's, and I was so used to where the buttons were, I constantly had to go to the options menu to try and make the buttons correspond to the same commands as the first game. I also found controlling the protagonist difficult. Something was so icky about the aiming of the gun, and I managed to miss my shots all the time, wasting ammo. And let's not forget the drill! The drill that ran out of fuel after using it 4 times! I ran out of ammo and fuel all the time, the hacking was never working. The controls never responded in time, and I preferred the old hacking system. The splicers were far from intimidating, and instead of thinking "Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ here comes those damn splicers," I thought instead "*Sigh*, not this again... -.-" Everything I loved about the original BioShock was gone. And why the Big Daddy? Why couldn't we play as, say, Tenenbaum instead? And after spending a long time struggling my way through a floor, my game crashed and I had to do it all over again. I came to the same spot - the game crashed again. I ended up quitting. Granted, that was probably my PC causing the problems, I couldn't bring myself to restart all the time. But my main problem with BioShock 2 is that I could never get myself to play the game. BioShock 1 made me WANT to play the game, but the sequelt I felt I had to force myself through to eventually get to BioShock Infinite, and I didn't enjoy it at all.BioShock 2 gets a 3/10.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												What was BioShock missing? Just think about it.Dual wield. You couldn't plasmid and weapon at the same time.Now you can.Moving on.  BioShock 2 places you in the shoes of the "feared" big daddy, so now you can kind of understand their plight. Not really though, because regardless you're still going to be murdering every Big Daddy you come across, as well as almost everyone else in Rapture. BS2 introduces new weapons like the drill, rivet gun, the speargun, the laser gun, remote hack tool, chaingun, your own deploy-able turrets, and more. While it expands upon much of the lore of Rapture and many of the characters, the story is not remarkable. Not only is the villain full of righteous condescension in a neutral way, but there never ends up being a confrontation with her directly - not even a meeting and a murdering like with Andrew Ryan. Really, the allure of this game was the improved gameplay over BS1. In addition to that, you can see a lot of areas that directly inspired Infinite or places where Infintie literally reused themes or assets, such as the infirmary.

Posted: April 1
												The popularly accepted theory that Jazz stemmed from a simple combination of African rhythms and European harmony is in need of a little revision. Both African and European rhythms were employed. African music supplied the strong underlying beat (absent in most European music), the use of polyrhythms, and the idea of playing the melody separate from or above the beat. European music provided formal dance rhythms. Combined, these rhythms give Jazz its' characteristic swing. Likewise, the harmonies and musical ideas of both continents are present, the blue notes derived from the pentatonic scale, "call and response" and unconventional instrumental timbres of African music together with "conventional" harmonies and, most important, the formal structure of European music. The multiplicity of ethnic, cultural and musical conditions needed to spawn Jazz was thus unique to the United States, and specifically to New Orleans. The necessary philosophical impetus for Jazz, i.e. , democracy and freedom of individual expression supported by group interaction, are also American institutions.

												Bioshock 2. This FSP takes you on an action/adventure of the future… from the past. Set on an old era circa 1940’s about eight years after Bio 1 where you play the antagonist known as Big Daddy. Keyboard controls or you can DL 360 profile from Pinnacle. This time the story line is more odd than the 1st. You begin by finding yourself come back from the dead in the not so abandoned ruined city of Rapture. A once noble Dr Sofia Lamb gone insane now rules with her own ideology. There are some old & new enemies, new versions of Big Daddy and an all new Boss known as Big Sister. In this version you’ll learn the spliced up denizens of Rapture see themselves as beautiful as well as the city itself as they all live under a false illusion. You’ll only learn this once you’re in control of a little sister. This game has much to offer in weapons and splicing ability as your still gather ADAM. The puzzles in game are a bit different such as hacking or combination code. Suit up and enjoy.

content:
Posted: March 21
												BioShock 2 is a linear FPS released in 2010 and is often considered the weakest link of the franchise, but it has arguably a better combat than BioShock 1.BioShock 2 has a unique art style, 60s music and a special libertarian underwater setting in a city called Rapture. The problem with the way the game is designed is that we never got to see Rapture before it had been destroyed. You just arrive and it's already in ruins. It's the same thing with the story. Most of the background story is told via old tapes that are about things happening we are never about to see. Everything has happened before. This game design is mind-bogging to me. What a waste of an opportunity!My biggest gripe I have with this game are the big daddies and little sisters. Basically, it goes like this: big daddies are huge mechanical dudes in deep sea diving suits that are mostly brainless and whose job is to defend the little sisters. Little sisters are little girls that are in danger of the splicers that are basically crazy junkies and want that sweet drug called adam that is in little sister's bodies. BTW, the sisters are crazy, too. You got the idea. I played through every Bioshock game and I never could get into this concept.++ Unique setting about libertarianism+ You can hold a gun and a plasmid (magic powers) at the same time+ Unique art style+ Good songs from the 60s+ You can upgrade your weapons and skills+ The game is still mostly decent looking+ Some memorable moments+ hacking is fun now+ the spear gun-- Major technical issues due to being a poor console port: Capped animations and physics at 30 FPS and low FOV default settings with no slider to adjust it.- Enemy type variety isn't high enough- Story is mostly told in audio logs. While I appreciate audio logs here and there, the story shouldn't be only told, but also more often SHOWN.- I didn't like the big daddies and little sisters- stealth is too simplistic- crashed a lot (until I changed to directx 9)Technical Adjustment Requirementshttp://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1142694If you want to play with animation and physics FPS higher than 30 you will need to play the remastered edition, which crashes a lot.Replay value: Low-averageRating: 6/10. It's an average game.Recommendation: No (except if you are digging that big daddy and little sister concept)

content:
Posted: January 13
												BadShock 2 does it again: poor shooting part, terrible sound and mediocre gameplay. Game is more balanced than the first BadShock - you will always have money for ammo; drill is useful as well. Most of fighting plasmids are useless compared to winter blast which allows you to kill any enemy in a couple of magazines. Hacking minigame became better, no more insane clicking. Game literally showers you with Adam so magic is more useful.Weapons are weird again. Rivet gun is just a bad sniper rifle since it can oneshot a low-tier enemy across the room. Hacking tool should've been moved to another button, not third slot. Why would they put a TOOL among WEAPONS is beyond my understanding (same applies to camera). Minigun is terrible and needs upgrades to shoot straight. Double-barrel is the best gun in the game (shock upgrade is useless). Spear gun is a joke since it requires aiming and projectiles travel slowly. Enemies strafe a lot so headshots with spears are almost impossible unless you lock them with electricity or ice, but then why bother with spears? Launcher is launcher, nothing unusual. And all of these guns sound horrible even with sound fix (maybe except upgraded shotgun).Enemies can be researched AGAIN, which means that you need to pull out that useless camera and start recording BEFORE actually doing something = wasted time and probably lost health. At least camera autoswitches to the last weapon after start of the recording unlike camera from BadShock 1. Blinking enemies are back as well for reasons unknown - probably that one guy in charge of them wasn't fired after the release of first game.Story is meh - go through the corridors to save the princess from her mother. Sound is broken even after fixes. Game has a nice chance to crash after playing an audiolog, so I gave up on listening to those after 4th level.Game is worth a single playthrough, there is no point in replaying it. 6/10 would not play again.

Posted: March 7
												Let me start by  saying the remastered version was so bugged, i couldn't get past the title screen so I had to play the original. That said, it was well worth the extra time to uninstall and install the original.Compared to the first game, 2 didn't take as many risks in it's story or gameplay. Rapture still holds wonder, but after playing the first one, it was less impressive.One thing to note is  you control a little sister for a part and get to see Rapture through her eyes. You understand why the little sisters seem happy and why they call the corpses of adam "angels". This shows possibly what Rapture was before the civil war and adds new awe. But this makes up only a short amount of the game. But what the story lacks, it makes up for in options. You now can make gamechanging choices (harvest/save little sisters and kill/spare 3 prominate figures) that effect 6 possible endings.The gameplay was slightly better. Finally, you can shoot while stunning people with electricity, but the upgrades of plasmids felt a bit clunky-having to hold down the button to charge up the increase in power made it feel so slow, i wouldn't do it once combat began. But at least hacking didn't take as long as it did in the first. Some new weapons and unique weapon upgrades also grace the 2nd game.The Music was amazing. It was much stronger than the originals and really created a stronger atmosphere.Characters: Not a single new character rivaled Fontine or Ryan. Lamb isn't bad, but was a strong enough follow up.Overall: Gameplay is slightly better, Story isn't as magical-but is still really good, characters werent as interesting.

												What a great game. I originally played Bioshock one on the Xbox a few years back and I had the sequel sitting in my library for a few months because I had forgotten how fantastic these games are. After picking it back up, I haven't been able to put it down with whatever free time I have left.Pros:- Very fun gameplay, the combat sequences are easy to get into and there are different ways you can go about exterminating the wannabe meth addicts aka "splicers."- Incredible story line. This really hit the spot I love games that have a very in depth story that draws you in like a good novel or movie and this game certainly delivers with a very powerful story line.- Visuals. The game is a few years old but graphically it holds up very well. I'm running it maxed out and, while it doesn't hold a torch to titles such as metro or crysis, the unique style of the game more than makes up for the aging textures.Cons:- It's a touch linear. This is a fairly linear game and it holds your hand throughout your play through. In certain areas this is very helpful, in others it sort of takes away from the immersion and individuality that I personally crave in video games. There are options in the menu that allow you to minimize the hand holding, but they don't completely remove it.- Sometimes repetitive. When you are taken to a new area and you have to back track to get this item to open that door to get that item to find this guy to open a door in the entrance can become rather tiresome. However, it isn't so bad that it ruins the game completely, sometimes it just become a bit tedious.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												BioShock 2 lends very few innovations to its predecessor. Wielding a plasmid and a weapon at the same time is a welcome change, but you won't find too many new plasmids here. The drill you receive is super fun to use, but unfortunately burns fuel (yes, you need fuel) rather quickly. You will find yourself in tight situations - be prepared.As far as the story goes, there isn't much difference between this and the original. You'll rescue or harvest little sisters and the ending will be influenced.The game doesn't really have anything poignant going for it until the very end, with a *very* interesting mechanic that could have been more thoroughly used. Overall, the game is mediocre compared to the original, and rubbish compared to Infinite. But you'll still find some play value in it, and those who have played Infinite will notice certain... commonalities.In short, buy it if you are lore-hungry or an achievement-hunter. But be warned: if you've played Infinite already, you probably won't want to play this past the first 20 or so minutes.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												The two most important components of BioShock series for me are definitely the amazing city of Rapture, that I wouldn't mind exploring in sandbox mode alone. The second one is obviously the story - the Ayn Rand-inspired ultraliberalist setting of the first game dragged you through more philosophical dilemmas than a sophomore course. Graphics, physics engine etc are all just secondary. Perhaps that is why for me BioShock 2 was definitely not as good as the first game. The gameplay IS better, that's true. The graphics ARE better. The story, unfortunately, is not. It feels a tad bit odd slaying big daddies, being one of them... A big part of the previous game was breaking the emotional bond between the daddy and the little sister. Now, I am not actually doing that; not to mention that the entire mission gets a bit tedious - slay the BD, gather two times, slay the BD, gather two times... I didn't have the sense of purpose like in the first game. My biggest problem with the game is the Big Sisters. Completely random, story-wise, no emotional connection whatsoever, and they honestly dont have a part for me in the game. I mean, the enemies overall are not very interesting; I did find the story of Splicers very awesome in the first game, but now it is the second iteration and I still have to grind through hordes of basically drug-addicts who are still superhard to kill (I mean you should be able to go through trash mob easily, but 8 headshots for a splicer? Come on). All in all, the game does deliver; however, it is clearly not as good as the first part of the series. In fact, I found myself trully waiting for the game to finally come to an end... Too much tedious grinding. Do recommend though, for a sense of closure :)

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Let me first say, Bioshock 2 is just as good as Bioshock 1. In fact, once I got used to the new Plasmid controls (tweaked slightly from Bioshock 1), I realized they had actually improved a few small things. So, now that you understand that I did in fact thoroughly enjoyed both games, I will list a few things that bothered me slightly about the story. These were not enough to detract from the overall enjoyment of the story, just some little things that were slightly *off* for me that I wish had been written to make the stories bend together better & provide more well thought-out continuity. The following contains spoilers, so if you have not yet played both games all the way thru, you have been warned.***********************SPOILERS***********************The ending of 1 felt wrong to me. ----------------------------------I loved playing both 1 & 2, the story had a great buildup and some nice reveals. When I got to the end of 1 and you suddenly made a clean escape from Rapture, it felt wrong. The ending does not affect gameplay, it is just a short cutscene after the fun final boss. But it did not feel like it really fit with the overall theme of the story. So then I start 2 and find out that you are now a Big Daddy and I got my hopes up that they had changed the lame ending to 1. You did after all spend the entire last half of 1 transforming into a Big Daddy. So starting 2 as one felt right & I was intrigued.I played the first 30% of 2 having a lot of fun, then spent the next 20% wishing it were shorter. That's only bc it started to get a little repetitive. No big deal really, just a minor complaint. Then suddenly just past the 50% mark, the story picked back up with a few big reveals about you. These alluded to you possibly being the same guy from 1. I was quite happy.There was no final boss in 2-----------------------------It's true. Some people may argue that there is in fact, a very large final battle that counts as an extremely hard boss fight. This argument is completely negated by the simple fact that as soon as you start the final event, you can (& should, by design) immediately skip the entire battle and go straight to the ending. I won't give away specifically how of course, but will tell you that by doing exactly what they tell you to do, you will not fight a single enemy in the end. It's kind of a mild let down after the big buildup you just went thru at that point in the story. I say you should do this, & by design, bc the final battle in question is completely un-winnable. Again, by design. They intend for you to do exactly what they tell you to do and  move on to the cutscene. I did however like the way 2 ended. The cutscene this time did make more sense in the grand scheme of the story.Sorry if all that rambling made no sense, just wanted to share my thoughts. None of this detracted from my overall experience of the games. I enjoyed both games and am very much looking forward to starting Infinite in a few minutes ;)

												I originally played this on the PS3. I'm not quite as fond of this one as I was of the first Bioshock, but that's kind of along the same lines as saying I don't like peanut butter as much as jelly. They're both solid games, and I would go so far as to say that the plot of Bioshock 2 is better than the plot of the original.What ended up letting me down in this one is that the environment isn't as nice. It's still interesting, I still wanted to explore it, but it felt so dead that I had troulbe really wanting to spend too much time in it. It wasn't until the last quarter of the game or so that it finally sunk it's hooks into me. The set gets pretty interesting around that point.Like I said, I think the plot of this one is better than the original. Sure the twist isn't as nice, but this story has more heart to it. It's just a shame that the gameplay and environment aren't as good. It explores the relationships that were some of the most interesting in the first game. The relationship between a big daddy and his little sister. The nice trick for this one is that the story is much more about liberation from social norms. I don't want to give too much away, so I'll just say that it mostly goes around how the big daddy character gets used for most of the game. If you liked the first one this should be right up your alley. If you're looking for something on the level of Bioshock Infinite you will probably be sorely disappointed. This game is pretty good, and it fits nicely with the original Bioshock.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												While the first Bioshock had the element of surprise on its side, Bioshock 2 is still very much a game that delivers. The combat has been revamped to flow nicer through things such as duel-wielding plasmids and weapons and a new real time (but sometimes still equally as frustrating) hacking mini-game. There are tons of new tonics, plasmid and weapon upgrades to experiment with, as well. On the story side, I found the father-daughter relationship that drives the plot as compelling as the first game's story. Obviously, Rapture lost some of it's survival horror feel, but it's still creepy, messy and twisted as ever. Bioshock 2 expands upon the setting in the first game and they've done a great job on that. Each new revelation and progression in the story keeps you playing, and while it might feel a bit "been there done that" it's still a lot of fun. It's a shame that there were so many technical issues though. The sound skipped, stuttered, or otherwise wouldn't play when I was in combat, crashing due to Dx10, and a bunch of jaggys because the engine doesn't support AA. I had to fix a lot of these issues by myself (time consuming as well), when stuff like that should be looked at by the dev team. it didn't change my perception of the game, but it would've been nice if there were patches. Having said that, Bioshock 2 is a great follow up to Bioshock 1. Reccommended.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Although it could never have lived up to its predecessor, BS2 was still a high quality entry into the FPS/RPG-lite subgenre and another well thought-out adventure into Rapture.  The sequel provides welcome insights into the Big Daddies and other aspects of the underwater dystopia that were not fully addressed in the original, in addition to building on the story some years after the events of BS1.  Not unlike the original, I think that FPS's that are this deep and story-driven have a difficult time ending, since they do not necessarily need the Big Baddie-style end game confrontation, but the expectations of the genre nonetheless require it.  With that in mind, I felt that BS2 did a good job of setting the stage for the final confrontation and then closing things off at the end in a satisfying and emotionally gratifying fashion.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												What makes me sad is that Bioshock 2 has been treated like the illigitimate child of the Bioshock series for far too long.  There is a certain beauty found in playing this game, and it has by far one of my all time favorite written DLC's that I have ever had the pleasure to play.  If you're on the fence about playing this game or simply don't know enough about it to jump here's my top reasons as to why this game is worth the second look:It shows you parts of Rapture you could only dream about.  At the end of the first Bioshock we turned ourself into a "Big Daddy" to complete our task and bring resolution to the "Rapture nightmare" but did you ever think that perhaps there was a much bigger story left to enjoy? Sure you could play the first game over and over again, combing through each audio diary but there still felt like there was more story to tell behind Rapture.  We never really got to experience "Big Daddy-hood" for its true raw nature, sure we wore the suit but what did we do with it? Nothing except use a sister to obtain our goal.  In Bioshock 2 they took that experience and gave us a more indepth look at the relationship of the Big Daddy and Little Sister.  We could explore outside of those collapsed tunnels, walk the ocean floor (while finding some Adam slugs on the way), and use the weapons we only dreampt about before.  We finally learn what it is like to care about the Little Sister as she gathers, and we are given more weighted consequences in our actions.The environment is still very much the Rapture we knew and loved from the first game and is filled with a wonderful cast of characters that really gives the game a new meaning.  Sophia Lamb is an enigma we just love to learn about, did she truly love the daughter she created or was there more behind her legacy than even she knew? Each plot twist lovingly crafted, leaving us at the edge of our seats until we reach the end and see the fruit of our labor.  How did we craft the daughter we may not have wanted? Our actions are given true meaning with every step we take, every moment we interact.  Now I'm not saying breaking a lamp has a tragic consequence, but the people we meet, the sisters we save or harvest, each one is weighted with a consequence.The DLC, I will always mention Minerva's Den when I talk about Bioshock 2 because it is really one of the best stories game-wise I have ever had the pleasure of playing.  We are subject Sigma, and our story takes place in the paralell of the main events of Bioshock 2.  As Tennenbaum said herself, "there are others I must save before the city drowns," this is what she meant.  In the final part of this game we learn about "The Thinker" the central hub of Rapture, the only thing capable of helping Tennenbaum reverse the "Rapture Nighmare" once and for all.  This DLC put the lid on Rapture once and for all, tying up any loose ends that we may have felt were left behind when Jack took the bathysphere to the surface with those little girls (err good ending anyways), and if you're the type that enjoy's a good "feel" from your games, this DLC really slams it home.Finally, though I could keep going forever about how much I love this game, it's a game that gives you many options on how you want to face the end.  There is no right or wrong way to play this game, much was the way with the first game.  True there are certain objectives you must complete, but there is no right or wrong way to achieve them.  You can be as thourough or as fast paced playing this game as you'd like.  It's a game that can be run in an hour 25 minutes or can be run in several hours, it's up to you.  I find I always get lost in the story and so I take my time, but others will run this game for the sport of it (as it will be run at the 2014 SGDQ), there is not right or wrong way to enjoy it, just so long as you have fun playing it.  So get up and grab your keyboard and mouse (or your favorite controller) and give Rapture a try, would you kindly?

Posted: July 24, 2014
												While this game failed to match the quality of it's predecessor, it's still worth a playthrough. It was said that one of the reasons Irrational Games did not participate in the development of this sequel was because they wanted to do something different other than just a standard return to Rapture, and unfortunately, that's precisely what this game did. The main villain, Sophia Lamb, felt like a weak attempt to re-create the sensational Andrew Ryan from the original Bioshock. I never really felt a sense of peril or impending doom while playing, I just sort of wandered through Rapture once more, waiting for something of any significance to occur. While the Big Sisters did prove to be a challenge, I would hardly consider the encounter with two of them simultaneously to be an excuse for the game's only boss battle. However, I still recommend this game for a number of reasons. One of those reasons being the fact that playing as a Big Daddy (Subject Delta) is TONS of fun. In the previous Bioshock game (and in Infinite, for that matter) the weapons you start out with are fairly weak, and you will most likely discontinue using them quite quickly. In Bioshock 2 however, the Drill that you start out with (and obviously never lose) is incredibly powerful, and the Drill Charge maneuver is a fantastic way to off pesky splicers in one punishing blow. Additionally, playing as a Big Daddy makes you feel even more invested in the Little Sisters, because they constantly praise you and look up to you for guidance and protection, and this may only apply to me, but it's an uplifting feeling.On another positive note, this game boasts a significant graphical improvement over the first Bioshock. Yes, it was released 3 years later, so improvements of this kind are expected and perhaps even thought to be a given, but one still has to admire Rapture with even more vibrant details. One small thing that I wanted to add, and this is about as nitpicky as they come, but I'm curious if there was a potential voice acting change with the splicers you confront on a regular basis? For some reason a lot of them sounded as if they were from Jersey, almost like the cronies you face in the Batman: Arkham franchise. Again, it's an irrelevant thing to complain about, but I couldn't help but miss the sound of proper insanity that the splicers emitted in the previous game, it added an undeniable eery element. Overall, I would give this game a 7/10. You're not going to regret it if you play it, and you're probably not going to regret it if you don't. However, if it's been your dream and intense desire to play as a Big Daddy since the first Bioshock, then this game won't disappoint in that department.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Even to this day, Bioshock 1 is a tough act to follow for any complex RPG-FPS hybrid game, and it was clear from the outset that Bioshock 2 had a lot to live up to if it was going to carry forward the legacy of its universally acclaimed predecessor. I feel that Bioshock 2 delivered. The combat is vastly improved, and the combat interface just feels smoother to use. The plasmid upgrades are a lot of fun and really shake up combat. The story is truly beautiful, and takes a distinctly different direction Bioshock 1. Whereas Bioshock 1 was more about exploring and learning about Rapture, and the failures in building a Rand-ian Utopia under the sea, Bioshock 2 has a more personal feel to it, exploring the lives of the common people of Rapture, the people who built Rapture and how it came to be. We also learn more about the Little sisters (which leads us to a great, unique sequence in the later game) The game continues to be as thought provoking as the first Bioshock, exploring ideas of the consciousness (as someone who has studied the neuroscience, I was captivated by the psychiatrist antagonist and her speeches), religion and love, very atypical subjects to tackle for a major FPS title, and this is where I feel Bioshock 2 pushes the envelope and really stands out. Bioshock 2 is visually and aurally sublime, through its great sound track and voice acting and gorgeous graphics.Playing as a big daddy really adds variety to the game play, through the use of the drill, ability to combine plasmids for special effects and underwater exploration scenes which really pronounced the ‘city under the sea’ idea.Due to Bioshock 2’s exploration of the history of Rapture, and the backstories of Rapture’s founding fathers, I found it actually served to enhance the story of Bioshock 1, further succeeding in its role as a sequel. Bioshock 2 will forever live in Bioshock 1’s shadow due to Bioshock 1 bringing so much new stuff to the genre. Bioshock 2 doesn’t do that, but it doesn’t need to. It succeeds in telling a compelling story, and making you care about the characters. This game is a must for any Bioshock fan, and I feel this game is criminally underrated by most.

												    I heard this game wasn't very good, but after getting it in the 2K humble bundle I gave it a shot. It's much better then most people let on. The biggest real complaint that it is very similar to the first game in almost every way, and by that I mean Bioshock 2 feels more like a expansion then a full blown sequel. It keeps all the strengths and weeknesses of the first Bioshock.  The story is filled with plot holes, but it's still pretty good. The characters themselves feel well written, even better then the original.     Most of the new weapons work differently but fulfill the same purposes as their Bioshock 1 counterparts. Although some of them are really enjoyable (Especially the Drill). The plasmids and gene tonics have been rebalanced, althought they still end up with the same problems as the original, some just end up being way more effective then others, I'm looking at you Winter Blast.  The biggest improvement would be that you can wield your plasmids and main weapons at the same time. The research camera returns in a new improved form as well as the same weapon upgrade system. The terminals that had allowed you to build things seemed to have been scrapped however. The hacking system has also been redone, it's not really better then the original, but it works. While there are some new enemies, most are recycled from the first game. Difficulty wise the game is not hard, I easily beat normal without dying once on the first playthrough.     The engine appears to be beefed up a little bit, but its not a whole lot different. There is still a lot of graphical beauty in the game, the attention to detail was not lost in this installment. Unfortunatly without some ini editing or disabling directx10, the game tends to have crashing problems for a lot of people.    At the end of the day I had a blast with this game. Sure it could have been more, but it still provides a fun experience. I'd definitly recommend it if you liked the original and can pick it up cheap on a steam sale or something.TL:DR Summary: If you liked the first Bioshock, this is pretty much more of the same and you will probably enjoy it.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												BioShock 2 is the sequel to BioShock, and is designed to continue the grand storyline of the underwater metropolis, Rapture. Set 8 years after the events of the initial game, BioShock 2 follows Subject Delta, a prototype Big Daddy brought back to life and sent on a quest to recover the Little Sister he was bonded to prior to his death, Eleanor, from the clutches of the new leader of Rapture, Sofia Lamb. He is guided through the decrepit ruins of the fallen utopia by former scientist Brigid Tenenbaum, seeking redemption from her immoral actions during her researches, and businessman Augustus Sinclair, who follows his own plans to escape the city.  BioShock 2 capitalizes and improves upon the high-quality effects, unique gameplay elements, and immersive atmosphere that defined the first game. With that said, there is its fair share of problems. For instance, this game CAN NOT be ran on its highest settings, as it will continuously crash at random times throughout the game. This game can only be played at Medium settings to avoid crashing and to actual be able to play this game. Which in my opinion, was a huge disappointment as I like to (As all PC gamers) play my games at the highest settings, and be in awe as I explore the underwater city of Rapture and be amazed at the beauty, and creepiness of the city.The combat in this game is very fluid, as was a problem in the first game. In the first game, you had to switch between your plasmids and your guns, which slightly slowed down gameplay and when confronted with multiple enemies at one time, became annoying. In BioShock 2 however, both your plasmids and gun are equipped at the same time, making the combat much more fluid and more responsive, and overall a much more satisfying experience.One thing this game brings that the first game lacks is achievements and multiplayer. The multiplayer is, in my own opinion, very fun to play. It's not the Call of Duty type experience people are used to, as this multiplayer is a "Different" experience to say the least, as both your plasmids and weapons are both a key factor in staying alive. The achievements are self-explanatory as you do something specific and get rewarded with a digital trophy. Nothing special, but it is fun when you beat the game to go back and try to get the achievements you have missed.Overall I can safely say that I 100% recommend this game to anybody who wants a very fun game to play. As it will keep you busy, with its fantastic story, great voice acting, and great combat.

												The Bioshock series has long been a personal favourite of mine, widely known for it's one of a kind plot, unusual settings, being loaded with twists, and generally having a game of tug-of-war with your emotions if you're one to play for the story. I rambled right there, and I apologize, however the fact remains that Bioshock 2 vastly improves on most of what players of the first game  despised; faster hacking, more fluid combat (dual wielding plasmids and a 50 cal machinegun is pretty badass), and bringing a large continuation of the first game's story. While I sadly played the 2nd game first, it's contents left holes all around, and as a result I missed key parts of the story. Only when I played the first game, did I piece the two games together, and as a result I knew every reference the game had to offer. NOTE: this game is not like your others, but is similar (catch 22) The main character (you) is sealed up inside a heavy duty diving suit, and is forced to travel through a city built in the style of the 1950's on the bottom of the ocean, battling drug-crazed people with guns (splicers), saving or harvesting the sources of the drug which splicers crave. This drug is ADAM, and the more you have, the better powers and upgrades you can afford, although to upgrade weapons you'll have to find special work stations hidden thoughout the levels. Your greatest threat is Sofia Lamb, an influential woman who has taken control of this underwater city (RAPTURE), and is determined to stop you from rescuing your 'daughter', Eleanor Lamb. (SEE THE CONNECTION?)

												Its a good game as a single player, but it sure has some annoyances as well.Lets begin with the graphics, they look almost identical to the first Bioshock. The difference between DX9 and 10 is hardly noticeable, however I did notice it runs a lot smoother on my pc. Running the game on an AMD A8 3870+6670DDR5 in dual graphics runs very smooth in 1080 with all the settings on high with vsync on!  Overall it runs a lot better than the first one. Controls, you can customize almost everything. Somehow at first the control movement feel sluggish, I had to increase my mouse dpi so it wouldn't feel so slow. After a while it becomes second nature.Sound, now here is a hit and miss. The game gives you the option to use Mono, stereo, surround, 5.1,7.1 and Dolby Pro. If you're using 5.1 it sure feels nice to hear how you can move around and you get to hear all sort of different sounds coming from different locations, you hear clearly when they come from behind. Now it would been nice if the weapons and explotions had that boom effect but saddly they sound rather weak, I'm not sure why and I'm not the only one other people also notice such the weak weapon effects.  The voices, the music and ambient sounds they all sound great, except the weapons effect.  Gameplay, its addictive, the story line is also good. A good change coming the CoD games. What I can't not understand why if you're playing as the big daddy its so weak? You got an enemy coming at you with a wrench or a flashlight and they hit you one or two times they almost kill you, I mean for the love god you're wearing a big♥♥♥♥♥armor suit and they are not wearing any protection but some of them take multiple hits before they hit the dirt. When you first fight the big sister its a pain to kill her, she is way overpowered, sure she gets to fire at you fireballs, can also use telekinesis, can climb on top of you to stab you, can run very fast. Meanwhile you move as fast as a turle, your mana drains like♥♥♥♥♥♥and your bullets are made of rubber, on the plus side your melee attacts are more effective.Conclusion, this game does not feel like a sequel but a rather large expansion pack. Totally worth it in my opinion. Update! Seems this game crashes on the level Fontaine Futuristics, when you save the game at the begining or in the middle regarless the game will crash and send you back to the desktop , event viewer doesn't show any problems with the game. For me the fix was to set the texture detail to medium that seems to do the trick.

												Bioshock 2 is my favorite game out of the series, so far. Many won't agree with that statement, but that is how I feel. Having said that I love all the Bioshock games, but something about Bioshock 2 really stood out for me. It plays pretty much  like the first game, but you play as Subject Delta. He is the first successful Big Daddy, before they started attaching the host to the suit. That means Subject Delta has a lot of human qualities still intact, such as the ability to use plasmids, and for the most part a human mind. Unlike most Big Daddys, Subject Delta has a mind and chooses who he wants to kill, based on the situation. The story is absolutely amazing, and I have beaten this game several times on the Xbox and now im playing again on PC. Plus the Minerva's Den DLC is my most favorite DLC that I have ever purchased. All in all this is an excellent game, and a must buy for new and returning Bioshock fans.

												Unpopular opinion time: This is my favourite Bioshock game.If you could hold back on the torches and lynches for a few moments  I will explain my position. The original bioshock was a masterpiece. What this game does is build upon that. It's a hard task to make a sequal everyone wants to a game that everybody loves, and so this game gets a lot of hate. But if Bioshock 2 had come out without the original ever being released, it would no doubt get the same praise the original did. The story, and more importantly the story-telling is perfectly crafted. There's a couple silly design choices like the image of the girl appearing when she's talking to you, which just come across as a poor attempt at being creepy. But beyond that there's a wealth of great story-telling. Audio dairies play a huge part again in immersing the player into the world, and the Lamb is a fantastic "villian" in that at times I was questioning whether she was indeed correct. I always find villians who's actions I can justify, to be far more impactful. The moment in the game that clinched it's place as the best in the series for me comes towards the end. I won't spoil it in this review but you'll know which moment it is when you get to it. It feels extremely calming and terrifying all at once and had me wishing it would never end for the duration.Like with the other bioshock games, I recommend picking up the triple pack since all 3 games are superb in their own regards.Also, make sure to get the Minera's Den DLC for another great piece of self-contained story with a great twist.
