												The second entry in the BioShock series is set in Rapture as the first game was and, yet again, is bloody brilliant.Most people who haven't/hadn't played the game (including myself) looked at BioShock 2 as the video game equivalent of a direct to video release. If this is what you thought, I urge you to give it a try.If you've played through the first BioShock, the setting and atmosphere will be very familiar, though set in an entirely different part of the city. This time around, Rapture doesn't feel quite as new and exciting as the first game, however the story and characters are still really compelling.There have been a few gameplay improvements, including hacking, general controls and a few weapon mechanics. The enemies are familiar, however a ton of new baddies are introduced.There may be a bit of trepidation going in initially as the original BioShock was so well crafted in story and characters, but I can assure you that you'll meet some very interesting and well written characters, as well as getting a more in depth look at the origins of the city and Andrew Ryan himself through audio logs.If you've beaten the first game and you're looking for more Rapture, you can't go wrong with BioShock 2.

												Let me first say, Bioshock 2 is just as good as Bioshock 1. In fact, once I got used to the new Plasmid controls (tweaked slightly from Bioshock 1), I realized they had actually improved a few small things. So, now that you understand that I did in fact thoroughly enjoyed both games, I will list a few things that bothered me slightly about the story. These were not enough to detract from the overall enjoyment of the story, just some little things that were slightly *off* for me that I wish had been written to make the stories bend together better & provide more well thought-out continuity. The following contains spoilers, so if you have not yet played both games all the way thru, you have been warned.***********************SPOILERS***********************The ending of 1 felt wrong to me. ----------------------------------I loved playing both 1 & 2, the story had a great buildup and some nice reveals. When I got to the end of 1 and you suddenly made a clean escape from Rapture, it felt wrong. The ending does not affect gameplay, it is just a short cutscene after the fun final boss. But it did not feel like it really fit with the overall theme of the story. So then I start 2 and find out that you are now a Big Daddy and I got my hopes up that they had changed the lame ending to 1. You did after all spend the entire last half of 1 transforming into a Big Daddy. So starting 2 as one felt right & I was intrigued.I played the first 30% of 2 having a lot of fun, then spent the next 20% wishing it were shorter. That's only bc it started to get a little repetitive. No big deal really, just a minor complaint. Then suddenly just past the 50% mark, the story picked back up with a few big reveals about you. These alluded to you possibly being the same guy from 1. I was quite happy.There was no final boss in 2-----------------------------It's true. Some people may argue that there is in fact, a very large final battle that counts as an extremely hard boss fight. This argument is completely negated by the simple fact that as soon as you start the final event, you can (& should, by design) immediately skip the entire battle and go straight to the ending. I won't give away specifically how of course, but will tell you that by doing exactly what they tell you to do, you will not fight a single enemy in the end. It's kind of a mild let down after the big buildup you just went thru at that point in the story. I say you should do this, & by design, bc the final battle in question is completely un-winnable. Again, by design. They intend for you to do exactly what they tell you to do and  move on to the cutscene. I did however like the way 2 ended. The cutscene this time did make more sense in the grand scheme of the story.Sorry if all that rambling made no sense, just wanted to share my thoughts. None of this detracted from my overall experience of the games. I enjoyed both games and am very much looking forward to starting Infinite in a few minutes ;)

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Back StoryLet me start by saying that I bought this game a couple of years ago.  Played it for about 10 minutes, closed it, and didn't play it again until recently.  Why you may ask?  Because when I bought it the game required some kind of account with Microsoft to save games in their cloud.  After creating this account, it still wouldn't save.  Think Uplay only worse (if that was possible).  Whoever thinks adding a "feature" like this to a game without any kind of benefit should be fired.  No ifs, ands, or buts... just fired (Still looking at you Uplay).For whatever reason, I recently decided to see if I could somehow get the game save issue to work only to find that this was completely removed in some patch.  I thank whoever had the good sense to put in local game saves so I could actually play this game.ReviewThe game feels almost like more of the same of Bioshock 1.  So if you did not like 1 you will probably not like this.  Personally, I loved the first, so I greatly enjoyed this one.  If this was all you needed to know, then buy it now.  You will love it as I have.The only negatives (if you can really call it that) that I found are some minor changes to how things work.  For example, hacking is no longer a puzzle.  Instead it is a simple thing of pushing the button at the right time.  Some people liked this new system.  I found it less mentally challenging, and less exciting when pulling off the perfect hack.The research system was completely changed as well.  Instead of taking snapshots, you have to run a camera on the target then shoot it with guns and plasmids to raise your score.  I liked the snapshots more, but the camera works.  Only real problem I had with it is that once you turn it on, it will switch to the previous weapon you had selected.  This wouldn't be a problem only it would occasionally change the ammo type as well.  Sometimes I would go through special ammo before realizing the ammo type switched.The other thing is that it this game is a bit harder than the first.  Enemies seem to respawn much faster, which can be a bit difficult in the beginning.  Once your weapons and plasmids are powered up and you have cash to restock on ammo, it becomes closer to the difficulty of the original.SummaryOverall it was an enjoyable game that you should experience.  Expecially if you were turned off in the past by the Microsoft version of Uplay.

												I kind of played the Bioshock series out of order. I played Bioshock 1 first and LOVED it. I immediately started Bioshock 2 and wasn't crazy about it, especially because there was no controller support at the time, and quit after the Ryan Amusements level.  I wasn't going to play Bioshock Infinite at first, but gave it a chance after it went on sale and ended up liking it a lot. So after Bioshock 2 dropped GWL, I decided to give it a second chance (especially since I'm fighting off the must-know-what-happens-next feelings after finishing Buried at Sea Part 1). I've made it pretty close to the end of the game B2, and I honestly just can't get into it that much. While it adds a lot of new information about Big Daddies and the state of Rapture after the events of B1, it's hard to see how it adds anything to the series after the introduction of Bioshock Infinite, because BI didn't seem to really reference B2 all that often ('Lamb' stuff withstanding). I also found the 'defend the Little Sister from swarms of Splicers" kind of tedious and annoying after awhile (since in the larger levels you essentially have to do it six times per level).

												Bioshock plus drills is pretty much the only to describe this one. What Bioshock had, 2 expanded upon and ran with it.The morality system is in place dictating certain dialogue sequences and ultimately the ending (of which only the extreme good and extreme bad seem to have any sort of visible outcome). The plasmids are back and so is the weapon leveling system with all of the same flaws (limited selection of what to upgrade so choose your favorites!). The collectibles are the same as ever including the audio logs and hidden easter eggs to search for in out of the way portions of the maps.All in all its a pretty good experience that can get repetitive if you use the same methods throughout the game (i.e. electro bolt and headshot with the rivet gun). Ultimately you decide how to enjoy/play the game and I like that in a game.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2011
												Bioshock 2 is the perfect sequel. Improved visuals much better represent the world of Rapture. Better gunplay: faster ammo switching and reloading, the ability to use plasmids and weapons at the same time, new, exciting weapons, better plasmid upgrades. Overall the gameplay is better: interacting with little sisters is more diverse, as you can carry them around and have them harvest adam from dead bodies, which triggers waves of enemies. You also attain the abilities of big daddies from the first game, such as the drill rush, which is pretty awesome. The narrative starts off a bit too obfuscated, but develops soon enough and quickly captures the player's interest. In the sequel a new ideology takes hold over Rapture, which is the exact opposite of what Andrew Ryan crafted Rapture to be. It's quite interesting to hear the two ideologues trade punches on the audio recorders. Bioshock 2 is the perfect complement to the original Bioshock game.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												This game is not new but even so the fun factor that is missing from so many games, is very high with Bioshock 2.  Achieves the rare combination of good graphics and non stop fun game play.  The tasks, abilities and powers you find for your character in the game, along with the story, are perfectly paced in such a way that it takes an awful lot of gameplay to even make you feel like stopping for a while. I am easily bored by a lot of games, and tired of wasting money on games I get bored of after 5 minutes.  As carefully as i try to choose games (by watching the YT  videos and the demo if they have one that works)...I often buy a game and just play it for a few minutes, then never play it again, because they lack fun factor and bore me to death.  Not this one.  The story is easy paced, introduced very gradually while you get used to the game elements, and the story progression is extremely well crafted.  Story pacing is genius, allowing you to simply take it  in gradually,  rather then beating you over the head with it as in "infinite".  It's easy to suspend your disbelief at the story, which is important,  because what a story you are living.  You are Subject Delta, an old time diving suit wearing, plasma wielding ubermensch with super human powers achieved by dosing yourself with "plasmids".  You are in an underwater city called "Rapture" (the story gets explained to you along the way as much or as little as you  choose, by dozens of tape recorders simply lying around  that you can play and listen to if you choose to). "Rapture " is an underwater city built in the late 1950's as some kind of social and corporate experiment.  Rapture has apparently lost its novelty and most inhabitants have left.  It is underpopulated and is fast becoming decrepit.  It is leaking seawater, breaking down, and slowly failing but is still filled with (hostile and drug addicted) human inhabitants, led by your nemesis Dr Sophia Lamb, the overlord of Rapture.  She is a perfect  villain who is a sort of female Heinrich Himmler, and she hates you with a passion for some reason.  It's clear she has no compunction to using and manipulating people,  including her own daughter, like a Dr Mengele in some kind of Nazi experiment while getting them to obey her at the same time. Dr Lamb  will regularly taunt you over the PA, and send legions of her subjects the "citizens of rapture" (the drug addicts) to come and attack you.  But you are more then capable of taking them on by yourself, since not only are you armed to the teeth with a metric ton of 1950's era weapons (shotgun, gatling gun, rivet gun, mini turrets, spear gun, rocket launcher et. al.) but you also earn, find and choose even more "biological powers"  (the "Bioshock" elements) that you emit from your own body like a lethal bad breath - these are powers (achieved by "Plasmids") that you find or earn as you go along.   The array of powers you can get to fight back against the hostile citizens of Rapture is impressive:  the ability to throw flame on people attacking you, stun them with electricity, throw small cyclones on the ground that will toss them in the air and injure them, freeze them into ice.  You can send out a scout to invisibly see what's up ahead and spot traps and enemies before they see you.  You can put out a decoy and watch as your enemies attack it while you hit 'em with a nasty plasmid or weapon.  And a lot more too. Every time you earn another plasmid, it is accompanied by an amusing 10 second long 1950's style black and white intro film that explains what you can do with it.  And the more powerful plasmids ("flame", "freeze" and cyclone trap plasmids) also have 2 or even 3 levels you can choose to make them even more powerful.  Along the way you  pick up, or buy ammo, cash, med packs, "eve" (the substance that powers your plasmids), booze, smokes, and free weapon upgrades.  You also get to hack or destroy all sorts of door locks, machine gun turrets, safes full of cash and ammo, and security cameras.  The game is  well designed and the all-important fun-factor as i said, is very high. Replay value is also high.  The DLC "Minerva's Den" is more of the same, but just as fun as the base game.  It is worth playing too.  IMO this is the best of the Bioshock games, the first one is just about as fun but the story elements are not quite as refined.  "Infinite"  is a good sequal and worth playing also, but maybe a little too refined is the only way i can describe it.  Sliding along steel cables in the air is not particularly fun and loses its novelty pretty fast, for me, nor does "Infinite" have much of an engaging story despite the hyper-realism and abstract philosophy elements that do little but muck up the gameplay. Not to mention, that dragging Elizabeth along slows down the story despite her eye candy appeal, which is all she is pretty much good for re. fun factor.  But it is this game that I find myself playing over and over.

Posted: December 18, 2010
												Like Bioshark, Bioshark 2: The Revenge is a game that isn't about punching sharks in the face with wrenches. Instead it's a game about picking up little girls and stuffing them into holes in the wall. That is messed up. Remember that episode of Star Trek The Next Generation where these crazy scientists engineered superhuman kids whose immune systems made everyone get all old and then Doctor Pulaski flew down to the planet to figure it out and got infected with it, too? Well, the little girls you stuff into holes are kinda like those superhuman kids - they don't get sick and they're pretty much immune to damage. The only real difference is that in Star Trek it was the kids' immune systems who made other people die, but in Bioshark 2 it's these big robot guys who do it. I guess those guys are a metaphor for the immune system - keeping the streets of Rapture clean and free of infection. ♥♥♥♥ man, that♥♥♥♥♥♥is deep.

												Why people insist on giving this game a bad rap is beyond me.The elements are fun to play with the standard electricity, fire, ice, telekinetic, etc now have upgrade teirs and all with their own quirks, the weapons sound and feel fantastic whether you're grinding someone down to pulp with an arm mounted drill or picking off that one splicer from across room with a well placed heavy rivet.The new gathering system is a added bonus allowing you to activate a horde-mode situation that allows you to gain a special currency AND all the items the enemies drop which could be anything from ammo to consumables.I played Bioshock and Bioshock 2 to DEATH on the playstation and even now i look back at my experiences fondly.As it stands Bioshock 2 is everything a sequel should be, it adds to the lore, expands the universe, throws in a few fixes and adds enough new experiences to keep the world of Rapture interesting.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												Story in Rapture continues.Bioshock 2 is improvement in many ways over the original game, but some of the charm was lost.The good. - Gameplay is improved.- You can now use plasimid and weapons at the same time, no more clunky switching with that. - Plasmids can now interact with each other even better I think, you can make a lot of different traps for example.- Cool new melee mechanics with the drill and a new charge ability, also tonic path to make melee only gameplay possible.- Little Sister interactions. No more brainless rescue/harvest. There's now option to help the little sisters harvest, but it's dangerous, but there's greater rewards. After helping them enough Big Sister shows up from time to time to check what's up, she's pretty scary.-New guns like the speargun, really cool stuff. Them physics.- Hacking is reflex game now rather than puzzle. You can remote hack any camera or turret and make them work for you. Hacked camera detects enemies for alarms and makes the whole security bot system work for you! Awesome!- Multiple endings. Up to 6 I believe.The bad.- Story doesn't just feel as great. Maybe it's the villain, maybe it's the locations. Something is missing for me.- Game engine is exactly same. I think visuals should have been better. FoV is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ without ini tweaks. Game crashes without making a few ini tweaks. DirectX 10 unstable perhaps?- Locations aren't really as memorable as in first game. Just a lot of ruins I find.- Level design doesn't seem to be on par with first game. There's some magic missing.Still a good 8.5/10. Gameplay improvements were great and multiple endings too. Locations, visuals, story aren't as great as with original.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Ah Bioshock, my first introduction to the joy that is the first person shooter. The original Bioshock has become a classic, even a legend, and became a hugely amazing argument for video games as art. Bioshock 2 brought mixed reviews from the fans, though, with some complaining that it wasn't nearly as good as the first and not liking the change of focus from storyline/gameplay to character development/gameplay. This was balanced somewhat by the cool factor of getting to play as a big daddy.As for me, I think Bioshock 2 is a solid and enjoyable sequel. Yes it has it's issues with a somewhat weak storyline but as I love character development I was still super pleased with the game. Bioshock 2 brings in new plasmids, new enemies, and new strategies for combat with your ability to now set up ambush/kill zones. 2 also works at fixing the lack of handicap from choosing to save the little sisters instead of harvesting them from the first game. The choices you make during the game all have more of an impact on the ending than in the first one which really only had two endings. Bioshock 2 has 3 main endings but, according to your choices, those 3 endings have several variations. Come back to Rapture and enjoy exploring the further devolution into madness and decay after the end of the first game. Explore further the evolution and creation of the Big Daddies and little sisters and see what future awaited the little sisters left behind when Jack escaped the city. Explore the DLC Minerva's Den where you play an entirely new character and learn even more about the city and how it works. You can also join in on multiplayer to experience the Rapture War first hand. The game definitely has it's flaws but like I said, I still find it a solid additon to the series and a very enjoyable game. Bioshocks 1 and 2 both hold spots on my Top 5 favorite games list.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												Despite everything that has been said about it, "BioShock 2" still manages to be a great sequel.Indeed, there is truth in the claims that the world is more 'empty' in terms of storytelling. The story itself is much more linear and personal, but that's what made the game special to me. Feeling that a Big Daddy feels was not only interesting, but oddly emotional. A lot of great moments are to be heard and seen in this game.The biggest upgrade has been recieved by the combat system. Here, it's significantly more fluid and rich, to the point of being insanely fun, in drastic contrast to the first game.This game does absolutely not deserve the hate it has been given. It's not to be disregarded in any way. And if you let go of expectations and comparisons, try to experience it as a standalone story in the same setting. That's the best mindset to go with.It's absolutely not as philosophical as the first game. But it's much more fun, intuitive and not at all less emotional. I recommend "BioShock 2" to everyone. And I will say this: different is not always bad. And new sometimes contains the "good" and the "bad". Some say the perfect blend of the two reasults in perfection. "BioShock 2" is not perfect, but it ain't that far either.

Posted: August 12, 2015
												Fun gameplay and good story. Really enjoyed playing this game even with its ups and downs. Pros - The main story as well as the tape recordings give more information on rapture and some of the characters from the previous Bioshock game. - New main story villains, they can get a bit annoying  so try to control your rage when confronting them, it affects the ending.  - New enemies added alongside some old ones. - Upgraded plasmids give new abilities besides a damage upgrade. - You now use Big Daddy weapons (Drill, Rivet gun, etc...) - More ingame choices (Six possible endings) - You can now carry little sisters and have them harvest adam. - Big Daddy dash ability, loved this feature. Beware it costs fuel. - Hacking things ingame felt easier compared to the first game. - New soundtrack alongside some copy paste soundtrack from the original game. (This is a pro because it didn't really bother me that much) - The Good ending.Cons - Your melee weapon (Drill) costs fuel, you can still smack enemies with it but i found looking for fuel annoying. - The only way to feel like a real big daddy is to play on "Easy" mode since you can get easily killed by splicers in the other modes which breaks immersion in the game. Easy mode basically makes you harder to kill and enemies weaker which did the trick. - Your Big Daddy footsteps now sound weaker compared to the first game. Maybe 2K thought players would get annoyed with hearing big footsteps the whole game.  - Some of the ingame weapons sound weak due to the latest patch; people have made a fix for this, but the fix crashed my game when i tried it, so i just got used to the regular sounds. - The game does tend to crash at random times so save your game often. - The "Save and quit" corrupts the save files for some unknown reason, you can still use the regular "Save".7.5/10 I wish this game didn't have the cons listed, otherwise I would have given a higher score. I do recommend getting this game when its on sale, you won't regret it.

												Bioshock was a first person horror shooter, with a deep story and amazong plot twist, although the gameplay wasnt too innovating, mostly allowing you to use spells and guns unlike most FPS's.Bioshock 2 is a first person shooter, where you play as a big person dual-wielding miniguns and firebolts, completely removing the horror aspect, the only horror being the dark world but if you want that, buy the first game.The Story is pretty bad and let's you play as "Delta" breaking all assumptions of what the Big Daddys are in Bioshock.If you want to feel like a juggernaut of horror tormenting the people of rapture whilst there is some weird, lorebreaking story going on in the background, buy this one.If you want to do that AND get a GOOD story experience, expanding the Bioshock universe and truly letting you feel like a Big Daddy form the ending plot-twist, buy Minervas Den and ignore the main game.8/10 because Minervas Den fixed the story, however most people consider games where DLC is required to make it good, a failure
